toString:
Using MongoDB 4.2.2. Community to view "users" collection

Reported in [https://app.slack.com/client/T0KQ4RZ24/C56DSBDHR]
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
To reproduce:
-Change the Connection string to include "///" such as

mongodb:///localhost:27017/?readPreference=primaryPreferred&ssl=false

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.
toString:
To reproduce:
 -Change the Connection string to include "///" such as

mongodb:///localhost:27017/?readPreference=primaryPreferred&ssl=false

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

 

When attempted with different connection strings that used to work, the connection string line is parsed inconsistently as shown by the error message generated (See images). Perhaps disable the "Connect" button if the parsing is not valid.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
To reproduce:
 -Change the Connection string to include "///" such as

mongodb:///localhost:27017/?readPreference=primaryPreferred&ssl=false

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

 

When attempted with different connection strings that used to work, the connection string line is parsed inconsistently as shown by the error message generated (See images). Perhaps disable the "Connect" button if the parsing is not valid.
toString:
To reproduce:
 -Change the Connection string to include "///" such as

mongodb:///localhost:27017/?readPreference=primaryPreferred&ssl=false

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

 

When adding the 3rd slash to different connection strings, the connection string line is parsed inconsistently as shown by the error message generated (See images). I expected the 3rd slash to generate the same error message for all variations. Perhaps disable the "Connect" button if the parsing is not valid.
author: felicia.hsieh

To reproduce in 1.20.3 (Stable):
 -Change the Connection string to include "///" such as

mongodb:///localhost:27017/?readPreference=primaryPreferred&ssl=false

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

 

When adding the 3rd slash to different connection strings, the connection string line is parsed inconsistently as shown by the error message generated (See images). I expected the 3rd slash to generate the same error message for all variations. Perhaps disable the "Connect" button if the parsing is not valid.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
On every installation or upgrade, Compass creates an icon for itself on the Windows desktop.

The desktop is not designed to be the primary way of launching apps, and cluttering it with uninvited icons is annoying to users.
toString:
On every installation or upgrade, Compass creates an icon for itself on the Windows desktop.

The desktop is not designed to be the primary way of launching apps, and cluttering it with uninvited icons is annoying to users.

This was fixed in COMPASS-3333 but it is present again in v1.20.
author: tom.hollander

-Make a Copy of a Favorite Connection

-Click "Favorites" button to Rename the Connection to something without "()". The new name is reflected in the screen, but not on the left-hand menu/list.

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

I have DevTools on, but no change to Console text

-Click the "Connect" button

-See screen try to connect but never give control back to user. Screen is grayed out with the thin, green progress line moving.

The database is very basic - no password, default port, localhost, etc.

Cannot delete Favorite connection, named "testtest (coasdfpy)". I clicked on the ellipse then clicked on "Remove", but nothing happens. I suspect it's related to the parenthesis that was auto-generated when I made a "Copy" of an existing Favorite Connection.

fromString:
Initial reports are users are inconvenienced/confused by the single line connection string format. Have answered a few Intercom Compass posts and heard a comment from Cloud Intercom also.
 # There is not enough field real estate to see the entire connection string in a glance. It's not ideal for enterprise customers with many replica set members, authentication options, etc. It would be useful to be able to see the entire string.
 # Users are not noticing the "Fill in connection fields individually" link to switch to the other view. Intuitively, it might be better as a toggle button.
toString:
Initial reports are users are inconvenienced/confused by the single line connection string format. Have answered a few Intercom Compass posts and heard a comment from Cloud Intercom also.
 # There is not enough field real estate to see the entire connection string in a glance. It's not ideal for enterprise customers with many replica set members, authentication options, etc. It would be useful to be able to see the entire string for debugging purposes.
 # Users are not noticing the "Fill in connection fields individually" link to switch to the other view. Intuitively, it might be better as a toggle button.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
Environment:
-Windows 10 64bit & Windows 2016 64bit
Steps:
-Run Installer (mongodb-win32-x86_64-2012plus-4.2.1-signed.msi)
-Press Next
-Tick Accept Terms in License Agreement

-Press Next
-Select Complete
-Press Next
-Check if Install MongoDB Compass is checked
-Press Next
-Press Install
-The Installer shows the ff.
!image-2019-12-16-10-17-10-178.png!


Expected:
-Should Install MongDB Compass

Actual:
-The MongoDB Compass is not installed only MongoDB Server is installed
!image-2019-12-16-10-21-01-402.png!
-Checked In Folder
!image-2019-12-16-10-24-25-425.png!
author: eric.sedor

toString:
HELP-12592 reports users with custom permissions see 0 collections in the sidebar due to [data-service instance-detail-helper not defaulting gracefully on {{isNotAuthorized(err)}}|https://github.com/mongodb-js/data-service/pull/142/files#diff-f92d390e3a3e59c4263281d8f8fd314cR115].

h2. Repro

1. Connect to VPN
2. Connect to TSE Testing deployment on atlas {{mongodb+srv://mansi1:mansi1@persistentcluster1-z01xy.mongodb.net/}} 
3. Connection succeeds but sidebar has 0 collections:

!Screenshot 2019-12-05 10.54.38.png|width=600!

{code}
mongodb-data-service:instance-detail-helper checking we can get buildInfo... +31ms
mongodb-data-service:instance-detail-helper user does not have hostInfo privilege, returning empty document {} +416ms
mongodb-data-service:instance-detail-helper isDataLake check: buildInfo.queryEngine +141ms undefined
mongodb-data-service:instance-detail-helper getCmdLineOpts failed! +3ms MongoError: not authorized on admin to execute command { getCmdLineOpts: 1, lsid: { id: UUID("a0258459-bd56-4387-9e6a-38b576d87134") }, $clusterTime: { clusterTime: Timestamp(1575560845, 1), signature: { hash: BinData(0, B3432FDC9B4B4F5FA738CCEF857CCBD6BFBBB589), keyId: 6717742709697675265 } }, $db: "admin" }
    at Connection.<anonymous> (/Applications/MongoDB Compass Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/mongodb-core/lib/connection/pool.js:443:61)
    at Connection.emit (events.js:182:13)
{code}

fromString: CLONE - gnome-keyring database decription error make Compass exits without errors
toString: gnome-keyring database decription error make Compass show a blank window
author: tommaso.tocci

fromString: The issues is triggered when [automatic database unlocking|https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GnomeKeyring/Pam] for gnome-keyring is disabled. In such scenario when Compass startup a password input popup window is displayed to unlock gnome-keyring database. If you just press cancel on the popup window Compass simply exits without any error.
toString: The issues is triggered when [automatic database unlocking|https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GnomeKeyring/Pam] for gnome-keyring is disabled. In such scenario when Compass startup a password input popup window is displayed to unlock gnome-keyring database. If you just press cancel on the popup, the Compass window will became blank end it will remain like that until you close it.
author: tommaso.tocci

author: felicia.hsieh

fromString: The Compass icon in the macOS Dock bar is larger than the other Mac icons but expected it to be the same size as the others. Please see attached pic
toString:
The Compass icon in the macOS Dock bar is larger than the other Mac icons but expected it to be the same size as the others. The current icon is 1024x1024, but other apps with circular icons only make the circle 898x898 and center it in the 1024x1024 image. The App Store, Safari, and Music apps are all good example of this."

Please see attached pic.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want the documents view to refresh when an import completes
 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection

h3. Acceptance Criteria
-
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want the documents view to refresh when an import completes
 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection and I am reassured that the import actually happened

h3. Acceptance Criteria
-
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want the documents view to refresh when an import completes
 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection and I am reassured that the import actually happened

h3. Acceptance Criteria
-
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want the documents view to refresh when an import completes
 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection and I am reassured that the import actually happened

h3. Acceptance Criteria
- When an import is successful and the user is looking at the documents view, the documents view should be updated to display the imported documents
- When an import is partially successful and the user is looking at the documents view, the documents view should be updated to display the imported documents
- When an import is successful and the user is looking at the aggregation view, the preview of documents should be updated to display (a sample of) the imported documents
- When an import is partially successful and the user is looking at the aggregation view, the preview of documents should be updated to display (a sample of) the imported documents
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user

 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection and I am reassured that the import actually happened

- When an import is partially successful and the user is looking at the documents view, the documents view should be updated to display the imported documents
- When an import is successful and the user is looking at the aggregation view, the preview of documents should be updated to display (a sample of) the imported documents

toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want the documents view to refresh when an import completes
 So that I can immediately interact with the new data imported into my collection and I am reassured that the import actually happened

h3. Acceptance Criteria
In the list below, "partially successful" means that there were errors during the import but at least some of the documents have been updated.

- When an import is successful and the user is looking at the documents view, the documents view should be updated to display the imported documents
- When an import is partially successful and the user is looking at the documents view, the documents view should be updated to display the imported documents
- When an import is successful and the user is looking at the aggregation view, the preview of documents should be updated to display (a sample of) the imported documents
- When an import is partially successful and the user is looking at the aggregation view, the preview of documents should be updated to display (a sample of) the imported documents
- When an import is successful the collection stats should be updated
- When an import is partially successful When an import is successful the collection stats should be updated
author: massimiliano.marcon

h3. User story
As a Compass user

fromString:
With this spike we want to determine what is the best way to run background operations in Electron. Web workers? Hidden electron windows?

When this spike is done, we know what we need to do to:
 * offload operations to background processes
 * cancel the operations running in the background
 * report errors that happen in background operations to the foreground processes
 * notify the foreground process when the background operation is completed and return the results when needed

A good place to start for a PoC could be import/export.

WIP scope doc is in WRITING-4477.
toString:
With this spike we want to determine what is the best way to run background operations in Electron. Web workers? Hidden electron windows?

When this spike is done, we know what we need to do to:
 * offload operations to background processes
 * cancel the operations running in the background
 * report errors that happen in background operations to the foreground processes
 * notify the foreground process when the background operation is completed and return the results when needed

A good place to start for a PoC could be import/export.

WIP scope doc is in WRITING-4477.

Some good material:
 * [https://medium.com/@david.gilbertson/should-you-should-be-using-web-workers-hint-probably-not-9b6d26dc8c6a|https://www.google.com/url?q=https://medium.com/@david.gilbertson/should-you-should-be-using-web-workers-hint-probably-not-9b6d26dc8c6a&sa=D&ust=1572864258379000&usg=AOvVaw3VXYTy79QTEfxGzyTz9-fF]
 * [https://slack.engineering/rebuilding-slack-on-the-desktop-308d6fe94ae4|https://www.google.com/url?q=https://slack.engineering/rebuilding-slack-on-the-desktop-308d6fe94ae4&sa=D&ust=1572864258379000&usg=AOvVaw0jzgEIguwbeu1TgzyHktio]
 * [https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/evaluate-performance|https://www.google.com/url?q=https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/evaluate-performance&sa=D&ust=1572864258379000&usg=AOvVaw2yDOEwRx0cAax2ihRoFuyd]
 * I found this talk pretty good: [https://www.infoq.com/presentations/electron-pitfalls/|https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.infoq.com/presentations/electron-pitfalls/&sa=D&ust=1572864258379000&usg=AOvVaw1VyReqCyf4JF63FiI0IHr4]
 * [https://blog.scottlogic.com/2019/05/21/analysing-electron-performance-chromium-tracing.html|https://www.google.com/url?q=https://blog.scottlogic.com/2019/05/21/analysing-electron-performance-chromium-tracing.html&sa=D&ust=1572864258379000&usg=AOvVaw1WMgswH8s3eM_86hGZwuCt]
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
Cursor hover on the Performance graph is not steady when moving the cursor out of graph.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the Performance page.
2. Let the graph running for a while and pause.
3. Hover the cursor over the previous timeline in a graph.
4. It is unable to place the cursor to the previous timeline to be able to move the cursor out of the graph in order to scroll the hottest collections box or slowest operations box. If move the cursor out of the graph, it will be placed at the latest time.
toString:
Cursor hover on the Performance graph is not steady when moving the cursor out of graph.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the Performance page.
2. Let the graph running for a while and pause.
3. Hover the cursor over the previous timeline in a graph.
4. It is unable to place the cursor to the previous timeline and then move the cursor out of the graph in order to scroll the hottest collections box or slowest operations box. Moving the cursor out of the graph, it will be placed at the latest time.
author: apinya.tepwankul

Message seems to originate in the compass-schema plugin (see https://github.com/mongodb-js/compass-schema/blob/e0bc33874e248465c27691f72f8a7893803b319a/src/components/steps/steps.jsx)
toString:
Steps to reproduce:

* Navigate to Schema tab
* Click Analyze

Labels are left on the screen when you navigate to other tabs. Was able to reproduce with a collection that only had the _id index defined (exact data below)

Setup:
- MongoDB 4.2.0 (Windows)
- curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mongodb/docs-assets/geospatial/neighborhoods.json | mongoimport -c neighborhoods

Tested using 1.19.12-Windows 


!20191011_061215.gif! 

Message seems to originate in the compass-schema plugin (see https://github.com/mongodb-js/compass-schema/blob/e0bc33874e248465c27691f72f8a7893803b319a/src/components/steps/steps.jsx)

toString:
Disabled {{SAMPLE MODE}} in Aggregations does not work for a high number of documents collection.

Steps to reproduce:

1. In Aggregations page, disable the {{SAMPLE MODE}}.
2. Use {{$group}} with below query. This will result in the count of the documents to this stage.

{noformat}
{
    _id : null,
    count : {
       $sum : 1
    }
}
{noformat}

3. The result displays the number of {{LIMIT}} configured or 100000 by default.

I was unable to reproduce in-house. My hypothesis is the number of documents plays a part in the issue. I do not see any document note that the SAMPLING will be force used if the number of documents exceeds X number.
Please see the below table that describes the relation of this issue with the number of documents in a collection.

|Number of documents in a collection|Disabling SAMPLE MODE Work?|
|-|-|
|26|Yes|
|1 million|Yes|
|1.3 million|Yes|
|6 million|No|
|33.2 million |No|
author: apinya.tepwankul

toString:
Disabled {{SAMPLE MODE}} in Aggregations does not work for a high number of documents collection.

Steps to reproduce:

1. In Aggregations page, disable the {{SAMPLE MODE}}.
2. Use {{$group}} with below query. This will result in the count of the documents to this stage.

{noformat}
{
    _id : null,
    count : {
       $sum : 1
    }
}
{noformat}

3. The result displays the number of {{LIMIT}} configured or 100000 by default.

My hypothesis is the number of documents plays a part in the issue and have asked the customer to test with other collections. Please see the below table that describes the relation of this issue with the number of documents in a collection.
Note, I do not see any document note that the SAMPLING will be force used if the number of documents exceeds X number.

|Number of documents in a collection|Disabling SAMPLE MODE Work?|
|-|-|
|26|Yes|
|1 million|Yes|
|1.3 million|Yes|
|6 million|No|
|33.2 million |No|
author: apinya.tepwankul

2. Switch to another collection. Query History is disappeared. User need to toggle again.
toString:
Step to reproduce:

1. On any collection, Toggle Query History. The Query History bar appears.
 2. Switch to another collection *or just open another tab*. Query History is disappeared. User need to toggle again.

toString:
$not cannot be used with regEx in MongoDB Compass 1.19.6 as well as latest version 1.19.12. The same query is working fine in Mongo Shell.

 

Query Example:

"{ name: { $not: /^H.*/ } }"

"{ name: { $not: { $regex: "^H.*" } } }"

 

Please see attached images.
author: apinya.tepwankul

fromString:
$not cannot be used with regEx in MongoDB Compass 1.19.6 as well as latest version 1.19.12. The same query is working fine in Mongo Shell.

 

Query Example:

"{ name: { $not: /^H.*/ } }"

"{ name: { $not: { $regex: "^H.*" } } }"

 

Please see attached images.

h4. (x) When I start Compass from master, I first get several keychain password requests. Then, after Compass loads and the connect screen is displayed, I get more password requests. This happens also after restarting Compass.

h4. (!) New Connection in the sidebar remains selected after clicking on a favorite

h4. (?) When selecting existing favorites, the SSL configuration does not seem to be set so the connection fails.

h4. (x) I don't seem to be able to connect to Atlas, even after setting the SSL configuration manually
If I copy-paste a connection string from the Atlas UI and add the right username/password to it Compass connects successfully. I am not sure if maybe the SSL configuration is not being passed into the connection model.

h4. (!) Copy is wrong

"you can sign up a free cluster using MongoDB Atlas" sounds wrong. The right copy is "you can *spin* up a free cluster using MongoDB Atlas"

 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail! 

h4 (?) Not sure what to do about this, but password is displayed in clear text when switching to connection string view

 !screenshot-4.png|thumbnail!

toString:
h4. Legend

(x) = blocker
(!) = major, acceptable in beta but can't make it into a stable build
(?) = I can live with it
----

h4. (x) When I start Compass from master, I first get several keychain password requests. Then, after Compass loads and the connect screen is displayed, I get more password requests. This happens also after restarting Compass.

h4. (!) New Connection in the sidebar remains selected after clicking on a favorite

!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h4. (!) Dropdowns don't look like dropdowns

 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 

h4. (?) When selecting existing favorites, the SSL configuration does not seem to be set so the connection fails.

h4. (x) I don't seem to be able to connect to Atlas, even after setting the SSL configuration manually
If I copy-paste a connection string from the Atlas UI and add the right username/password to it Compass connects successfully. I am not sure if maybe the SSL configuration is not being passed into the connection model.

h4. (!) Copy is wrong

"you can sign up a free cluster using MongoDB Atlas" sounds wrong. The right copy is "you can *spin* up a free cluster using MongoDB Atlas"

 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail! 

h4. (?) Not sure what to do about this, but password is displayed in clear text when switching to connection string view

 !screenshot-4.png|thumbnail! 

h4. (!) When I select a favorite and switch to "connection string view" I am actually switched back to "new connection"

When I select a favorite, it is displayed by default in "individual fields" mode. When I click on "Paste connection string", I am switched to creating a new connection.
This could make sense and might also somehow solve the problem above (password in clear text) but the UX feels a bit weird.
There is also a use-case of users wanting to copy the connection string to use e.g. with the shell that we may want to keep in mind.

 !Aug-30-2019 09-42-57.gif!

toString:
h4. Legend

(x) = blocker
 (!) = major, acceptable in beta but can't make it into a stable build
 (?) = I can live with it
----
h4. (x) When I start Compass from master, I first get several keychain password requests. Then, after Compass loads and the connect screen is displayed, I get more password requests. This happens also after restarting Compass.

Update: the double round of keychain requests does not happen anymore, but I still see one round of keychain requests every time I open Compass. That's why I put COMPASS-3235 into the sprint.


h4. (!) New Connection in the sidebar remains selected after clicking on a favorite

!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
h4. (?) When selecting existing favorites that were migrated, the SSL configuration does not seem to be set so the connection fails.
h4. (x) For existing favorites that were migrated I don't seem to be able to connect to Atlas, even after setting the SSL configuration manually
If I copy-paste a connection string from the Atlas UI and add the right username/password to it Compass connects successfully. I am not sure if maybe the SSL configuration is not being passed into the connection model (attaching an example of favorite that was migrated vs the same favorite re-created by copy-pasting the connect string from Atlas).

h4. (?) Not sure what to do about this, but password is displayed in clear text when switching to connection string view

!screenshot-4.png|thumbnail!
h4. (!) When I select a favorite and switch to "connection string view" I am actually switched back to "new connection"

When I select a favorite, it is displayed by default in "individual fields" mode. When I click on "Paste connection string", I am switched to creating a new connection.
 This could make sense and might also somehow solve the problem above (password in clear text) but the UX feels a bit weird.
 There is also a use-case of users wanting to copy the connection string to use e.g. with the shell that we may want to keep in mind.

!Aug-30-2019 09-42-57.gif!
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString: This issue is documented by DOCSP-7105
author: edu.bot

toString:
This task is about replacing the backend of the feature with community-maintained libraries that are battle-tested for CSV and JSON parsing/creation.

This is timeboxed to 1 week and the main goal is that after this is done, Import/Export in Compass *with the existing UX* works reliably, no matter the size of the collection:
* CSV are exported according to the CSV spec and can be imported back
* JSON is imported with no errors. For the time being, since we don't change the UX, it's ok to still only support JSONL but let's keep in mind that eventually we want to also support JSON arrays. JSON is also exported with no errors, and an exported JSON can be imported back.

If we are unable to make this work, we will fallback to using mongoimport/mongoexport.
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to select the fields that will be written into the exported JSON or CSV file
 So that I only export what is needed and I can keep the file small

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Before exporting, the user can choose the fields that are exported (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/349364209)
 - When fields are selected/deselected, if a projection exists, it is modified according to the new selection
 - Because the list of fields is probably generated from a sample of the collection, we give the user the possibility of adding other fields that may not exist in the sample
 - When the export is completed, only the fields that the user selected are exported
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
Refresh the Indexes page does not reflect index operation outside Compass.

Scenario:
 # Connect to mongod via MongoDB Compass.
 # Connect to the same mongod and create/drop index via Mongo Shell.
 # Refresh MongoDB Compass using cmd+R or databases circular arrow will not reflect the index operation done via Shell.

Customer Intercom:

[https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/3373509/conversations/23303638788]

author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
As a Compass user
 I want to contextual entry points to import/export
 So that I can find and access the functionality where I needed

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - The contextual menu in the Collections view contains an entry point to Import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135807).
 - The contextual menu for a collection in the side bar contains an entry point to Import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135808).
 - The empty state of the documents tab contains an entry point to Import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135808)
 - The toolbar of the documents tab contains an entry point to Import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135808)
 - The entry point to Import opens the Import dialog in the context of the collection the user selected
 
 - The contextual menu in the Collections view contains an entry point to Export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135807).
 - The contextual menu for a collection in the side bar contains an entry point to Export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135808).
 - The entry point to Export opens the Export dialog in the context of the collection the user selected. By default, the whole collection will be exported.

 - The toolbar of the documents tab contains an entry point to Export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/316135808)
 - When Export is selected in the documents tab toolbar, Export defaults to the current filter, project, sort and limit

h3. Notes
 - This story is only worth doing once the new implementation for import/export is ready.

fromString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to import documents from a JSON file
 So that I can quickly seed my collection with existing data

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Compass can import a valid JSON file (an array of documents, COMPASS-3185)
 - Compass cam import extended JSON (COMPASS-3384)
 - Compass can import a valid JSONL file (http://jsonlines.org/)
 - When an error happens during the import
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to import
 - When the JSON is invalid
 ** Compass displays a meaningful error (COMPASS-3755)
toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to import documents from a JSON file
 So that I can quickly seed my collection with existing data

h3. Acceptance Criteria

 - When an error happens during the import
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to import
 - When the JSON is invalid
 ** Compass displays a meaningful error (COMPASS-3755)

h3. Notes
 - JSONL = whatever is the spec that mongoimport handles
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to export documents as a JSON
 So that I use my data with other tools

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Compass can export documents to a valid (extended) JSON file
 - When filter, project, sort or limit are specified for the collection the user is exporting, the user has the option to use them as the settings for the export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/347756471)
 - When an error happens during the export
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to export

h3. Notes
 - Note that I am suggesting we export valid JSON instead of JSON lines. Valid JSON makes more sense because it can be used also with tools outside the MongoDB ecosystem
toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to export documents as a JSON
 So that I use my data with other tools

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Compass can export documents to a valid (extended) JSON file
 - When filter, project, sort or limit are specified for the collection the user is exporting, the user has the option to use them as the settings for the export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/347756471)
 - When an error happens during the export
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to export

h3. Notes
 - Note that I am suggesting we export valid JSON instead of JSON lines. Valid JSON makes more sense because it can be used also with tools outside the MongoDB ecosystem
 - In the export screen (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/347756471) the code snippet with filter, project, sort or limit is not editable
 - We export the result of the query (or the full dataset) and not only what is displayed by Compass in the first page of results
author: massimiliano.marcon

 So that I use my data with other tools

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Compass can export documents to a valid (extended) JSON file
 - When filter, project, sort or limit are specified for the collection the user is exporting, the user has the option to use them as the settings for the export (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/347756471)
 - When an error happens during the export
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to export
 - During the export, progress is displayed in the export modal

h3. Notes
 - Note that I am suggesting we export valid JSON instead of JSON lines. Valid JSON makes more sense because it can be used also with tools outside the MongoDB ecosystem
 - In the export screen (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/347756471) the code snippet with filter, project, sort or limit is not editable
 - We export the result of the query (or the full dataset) and not only what is displayed by Compass in the first page of results
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to import documents from a CSV file
 So that I can quickly seed my collection with existing data that may come from non-MongoDB tools

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Compass can import data from a CSV file (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/334176863)
 - It is possible to select the delimiter (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/334176863)
 - It is possible to use the headerline for the field names (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/334176863)
 - When an error happens during the import
 ** Compass shows a meaningful error message
 ** Compass says how many documents it managed to import

h3. Notes
 - Lucas at some point suggested a CSV parsed better than what Compass uses now (COMPASS-3129)
 - Note that selecting fields and their types is not part of this story

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want to specify the fields I want to import from CSV and their types
 So that I can control what data I want to have in my collection and specify the schema

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Before the CSV import starts, users can select the fields that are included in the import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/344502152, COMPASS-2956)
 - For the fields that are included in the import, users can specify their types (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/344502152)
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
 I want to specify the fields I want to import from CSV and their types
 So that I can control what data I want to have in my collection and specify the schema

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 - Before the CSV import starts, users can select the fields that are included in the import (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/344502152, COMPASS-2956)
 - For the fields that are included in the import, users can specify their types (https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/BVNOZB4DYT3#/screens/344502152)

h3. Notes
 - We pre-read a portion of the CSV file (headerline and a few lines) to display the preview in the field/type selector.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
MongoDB download center (https://www.mongodb.com/download-center) changed linux URLs format, therefore `download-url` module (https://github.com/mongodb-js/download-url) should be updated to properly parse new urls.

The last PR closed by driver team (https://github.com/mongodb-js/download-url/pull/81) didn't fix the problem and causes builds failure:

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/imlucas/mongodb-version-manager/builds/26671340

When the problem will be fixed:

1) `version-manager` module (https://github.com/mongodb-js/version-manager) should be updated to the new version of `download-url`.

2) `runner` module (https://github.com/mongodb-js/runner) should be updated to the new version of `version-manager`.

3) `connection-model` and `data-service` should be updated to the new version of `runner`.

4) `data-service` should be updated to the new version of `connection-model`.

5) `compass-home` and `compass-ssh-tunnel-status` should be updated to the new version of `connection-model` and `data-service.

6) Compass should be updated to use all these new versions
toString:
SERVER-37316 updated the filename scheme for release artifacts. We need to update our tools for CI and day to day dev to account for this.

There was a recent [PR|https://github.com/mongodb-js/download-url/pull/81] to address this but it wasn't long term and causes build failures such as [this|https://ci.appveyor.com/project/imlucas/mongodb-version-manager/builds/26671340].

When the problem will be fixed:

1. Assist with DEVOPS-1246 to reconfigure [the prototype|https://github.com/imlucas/version.mongodb.parts] from TECHOPS-2985 to work on Kanopy and use STAR full.json release manifest
2. [{{mongodb-version-manager}}|https://github.com/mongodb-js/version-manager] becomes a mono repo (request from [~matt.broadstone] NODE-2062)
3. Write a script to update dependencies in package.json for all new releases 

h4. Notes

- Not for tracking in Compass roadmap. Glue work that needs to be done but has fallen through the cracks and hurting productivity.
- COMPASS-4033 Script for cleaning up devDependencies in compass plugin template and existing plugins
- COMPASS-3160 Long term fix instead of manual scripting for updating dependencies
- SERVER-36098
- https://github.com/mongodb-js/version-manager/issues/151
- INT-237
- INT-488
- NODE-1245
- NODE-2062
- https://github.com/aheckmann/m
- https://www.npmtrends.com/m-vs-mongodb-version-manager-vs-mongodb-download-vs-mongodb-prebuilt-vs-mongodb-runner
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: Download-url should add support for ubuntu distros for v4
toString: parts: mongodb-download-url should add support for ubuntu distros for v4
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString:
Reported by user, [https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/unassigned/conversations/23234271159]
"I updated the mongo compass today and it no longer refreshes data with cmd+r.
it acts like it refreshes, but no new entires show up until I navigate to another collection and back"
 
This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) has no effect either. Only moving to another collection and back refreshes the data.
toString: This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) has no effect either. Only moving to another collection and back refreshes the data.
author: brian.blevins

fromString: This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) has no effect either. Only moving to another collection and back refreshes the data.
toString:
This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) has no effect either. Only moving to another collection and back refreshes the data.

This bug also exists in 1.19.3 Stable, but the label for this cannot seem to be added.
Also tested in 1.19.3 Stable is using the menu, "View>Reload". It does not refresh either.
Using the ellipses on the collection to "Open in New Tab" does a successful refresh.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) has no effect either. Only moving to another collection and back refreshes the data.

This bug also exists in 1.19.3 Stable, but the label for this cannot seem to be added.
Also tested in 1.19.3 Stable is using the menu, "View>Reload". It does not refresh either.
Using the ellipses on the collection to "Open in New Tab" does a successful refresh.
toString:
This was reproduced using a default mongo shell connection and changed the collection data (with db.collection.insert command) while viewed in Compass. The Compass "cursor" was on the collection name before the Cmd-r press. Pressing Cmd-r, flashed text of "Loading databases" and a progress bar appears, but the collections data is not refreshed. Pressing the "Reload" icon (clockwise circular arrow) on the LEFT sidebar has no effect either but was expected.
Moving to another collection and back successfully refreshes the data.
Clicking the circular arrow on the RIGHT (near "Displaying Documents...") successfully refreshes the data.

This bug also exists in 1.19.3 Stable, but the Jira label for this release cannot seem to be added.
 Also tested in 1.19.3 Stable is the menu command "View>Reload". It does not refresh either.
 Using the ellipses on the collection to "Open in New Tab" does a successful refresh.
author: felicia.hsieh

fromString:
Inserting or updating int64 data type by hand or copy and paste keep the value changing automatically.

Customer's quote:
{quote}For example, trying to type in an int64 number of 252602384126050305 by hand results in 252602384126050336, while pasting it in results in 252602384126050304. It seems that the last two digits that you type are never the same as what compass actually registers.
{quote}
Those numbers are still in Int64 range. It is reproducible on my machine and [~irina.shestak].

Intercom: [https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/3373509/conversations/23106920650]. 

Customer's provided screen shot:

!Screen Capture on 2019-08-07 at 17-30-51.gif!

toString: Users can now click on the polygon icon to draw polygons on maps as well as circles. Polygons can be combined with circles. Circles generate a $geoWithin with $centerSphere and Polygons generate $geoWithin/$geometry/Polygon queries. When used in conjunction with each other statements are combined in an $or.

toString:
During the keynote at MDBW, we had an issue during the creation of a wildcard index: https://youtu.be/SODvhxJnAcI?t=3003

Here is how to reproduce it (almost) consistently:
* compass-data-sets, {{sample_airbnb. listingsAndReviews}}
* Create index "wildcard", index definition {{$**}} {{1 (asc)}}
* Click "Create index"

Compass 1.19: shows error in the screenshots.
Compass master: timeout error

In both cases the index is created.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
During the keynote at MDBW, we had an issue during the creation of a wildcard index: https://youtu.be/SODvhxJnAcI?t=3003

Here is how to reproduce it (almost) consistently:
* compass-data-sets, {{sample_airbnb. listingsAndReviews}}
* Create index "wildcard", index definition {{$**}} {{1 (asc)}}
* Click "Create index"

Compass 1.19: shows error in the screenshots.
Compass master: timeout error

In both cases the index is created.
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
During the keynote at MDBW, we had an issue during the creation of a wildcard index: https://youtu.be/SODvhxJnAcI?t=3003

Here is how I could reproduce it twice and then never again:

Compass 1.19:
* compass-data-sets, {{sample_airbnb. listingsAndReviews}}
* Create index named "wildcard", index definition {{$**}} {{1 (asc)}}
* Click "Create index"
* *shows error in the screenshots.*

Then Compass master:
* delete "wildcard" on {{sample_airbnb. listingsAndReviews}}
* Create index named "wildcard", index definition {{$**}} {{1 (asc)}}
* Click "Create index"
* *shows timeout error*

In both cases the index is created.

Note that this *is not specific to wildcard indexes*: other users had errors with regular indexes too.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to create a new document in extend JSON
 So that I can easily copy paste from my code editor or from an API response

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - There is a new JSON mode in the "new document" dialog
 - It's possible to paste extended JSON in a code editor with syntax checking and highlighting
 - It's possible to switch between JSON and "field by field" mode and the changes made in one mode are preserved and visible in the other mode
toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to create a new document in extend JSON
 So that I can easily copy paste from my code editor or from an API response

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - There is a new JSON mode in the "new document" dialog
 - It's possible to paste extended JSON in a code editor with syntax checking and highlighting
 - It's possible to switch between JSON and "field by field" mode and the changes made in one mode are preserved and visible in the other mode
 - It's possible to insert a new document only if the JSON is valid
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString: This issue is documented by DOCSP-6508
author: edu.bot

fromString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to see and edit documents in extended JSON
 So that I have a way to work in an environment that is similar to my code editor where I feel productive

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - There is a new JSON mode alongside the existing default (list) and table modes.
 - In JSON mode, the extended JSON of the documents will be displayed
 - In JSON mode, it is possible to edit documents in a code editor with syntax highlighting for (extended) JSON. Copy-paste should work

h3. Notes
 - If we display encrypted fields as {{*******}} also in JSON mode, can we prevent the user from updating them?
toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to see and edit documents in extended JSON
 So that I have a way to work in an environment that is similar to my code editor where I feel productive

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - There is a new JSON mode alongside the existing default (list) and table modes.
 - In JSON mode, the extended JSON of the documents will be displayed
 - In JSON mode, it is possible to edit documents in a code editor with syntax highlighting for (extended) JSON. Copy-paste should work
 - In JSON mode, like with the other modes, only one document at a time can be edited.

h3. Notes
 - If we display encrypted fields as {{*******}} also in JSON mode, can we prevent the user from updating them?
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
h3. User story

As a Compass user
 I want to see and edit documents in extended JSON
 So that I have a way to work in an environment that is similar to my code editor where I feel productive

h3. Acceptance criteria
 - There is a new JSON mode alongside the existing default (list) and table modes.
 - In JSON mode, the extended JSON of the documents will be displayed
 - In JSON mode, it is possible to edit documents in a code editor with syntax highlighting for (extended) JSON. Copy-paste should work
 - In JSON mode, like with the other modes, only one document at a time can be edited.

h3. Notes
 - If we display encrypted fields as {{*******}} also in JSON mode, can we prevent the user from updating them? Sounds like this is a yes, as ACE editor allows us to set lines as read-only.

toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to know what fields are encrypted with FLE
So that I understand why I can't see the content of the field and I know I should not attempt to modify the content of the field

h3. Acceptance criteria
- FLE-encrypted fields (binary with subtype 6) are displayed with some visual indication that the field is encrypted both in normal mode as well as in table mode

h3. Questions
- Is it easy to prevent the user to modify the field? Some sort of field specific read-only mode?
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
Compass users often want to be able to export the results of any query they can compose in the Compass UI. That includes rich query options such as projection (not yet implemented as per COMPASS-2843) and aggregations.

The current behaviour (as of v1.17.0) is that for a current aggregation pipeline the Export interface will only pick up the $match stage to be used as an export query. All of the other stages are ignored.

This is a pain for users as they have to fall back to {{mongo}} shell or 3rd party GUI solutions.
toString:
Compass users often want to be able to export the results of _any_ query they can compose in the Compass UI. That includes rich query options such as projection (not yet implemented as per COMPASS-2843) and aggregations.

The current behaviour (as of v1.17.0) is that for a current aggregation pipeline the Export interface will only pick up the $match stage to be used as an export query. All of the other stages are ignored.

This is a pain for users as they have to fall back to {{mongo}} shell or 3rd party GUI solutions.
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:
Compass users often want to be able to export the results of _any_ query they can compose in the Compass UI. That includes rich query options such as projection (not yet implemented as per COMPASS-2843) and aggregations.

The current behaviour (as of v1.17.0) is that for a current aggregation pipeline the Export interface will only pick up the $match stage to be used as an export query. All of the other stages are ignored.

This is a pain for users as they have to fall back to {{mongo}} shell or 3rd party GUI solutions.
toString:
Compass users often want to be able to export the results of _any_ query they can compose in the Compass UI. That includes rich query options such as projection (not yet implemented as per COMPASS-2843) and aggregations.

The current behaviour (as of v1.17.0) is that for a current aggregation pipeline the Export interface will not construct a query. All of the stages are ignored.

This is a pain for users as they have to fall back to {{mongo}} shell or 3rd party GUI solutions.
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:

Open question: Should changing just name also save all changed connection properties in the current saved favorite connection?

fromString:
It should be possible to specify a name for the current connection and save it to favorites.

Open questions:
- How to save a connection without changing the name?
- Should changing just name also save all connection properties in the current saved favorite connection
toString:
It should be possible to specify a name for the current connection and save it to favorites.

Open question: How to save a connection without changing the name? There is some example in design that host is being used as a default name, but in this case, the design is missing save icon.
author: alena.khineika

fromString:
It should be possible to add a label to the current connection. Add `Add label` button to the connection form that opens a popup, where a user can specify a name and background color for the current connection. User can save or cancel changes. The specified label should be displayed after saving on the connection screen.

Open question: How to delete a label?
toString: It should be possible to add a color label to the current connection.

fromString: Connection Model Supports All URI Options
toString: Connection model should parse all URI options
author: alena.khineika

fromString:
Update the connection model to support all options that the connection string can have.

 
 # Add all additional options as attributes to the connection model that can be specifed. ([https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/connection-string/)]
 # Ensure that the connection model sets the appropriate attributes when parsing a uri, and can generate a correct URI (driver_url) from all attributes set.
toString:
Update the connection model to parse all connection options that URI can have. Use the node driver URI parser for it instead of mongodb-url.

- Replace mongodb-js/url parser with parseConnectionString from mongodb-js/mongodb-core
- Update tests according to changes in the code
- Add tests for parsing URI
- Update returning object structure

For more info the about connection string: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/connection-string/
author: alena.khineika

fromString:
With the recent travis acquisition I am a little uncertain about the future of travis as the service we started using way back when. With a lot of support engineers from travis getting let go, it worries me that maintenance and future development of this product might stagnate.

I've heard quite a few people switching to azure pipelines and having great success with it, and wanted to take a little bit of time on whether it's worth considering switching over as well.
toString:
With the recent travis acquisition I am a little uncertain about the future of travis as the service we started using way back when. With a lot of support engineers from travis getting let go, it worries me that maintenance and future development of this product might stagnate.

I've heard quite a few people switching to azure pipelines and having great success with it, and wanted to take a little bit of time on whether it's worth considering switching over as well.

Three points:


1) i _feel_ like travis builds are now taking a lot longer to run (this needs proper numbers)
2) they let go _a lot_ of engineers two months ago and I feel like the product is now in bare-bones maintenance mode; i am weary to rely on it
3) it’s now owned a by VC firm and that never goes well \o/
author: irina.shestak

fromString:
Studio3T have quite an advanced [SQL to MongoDB Migration|https://studio3t.com/knowledge-base/articles/sql-to-mongodb-migration/#introduction] wizard. It seems to be able to connect to any [SQL Server|https://studio3t.com/knowledge-base/articles/sql-to-mongodb-migration/#connect-to-a-sql-server]  and includes some UI for defining relationships between tables to create structured documents with arrays etc during the import process. 

Since we don't have any official/home-grown tools for transforming SQL data during import, I think Compass would be a great place to introduce such a feature. 

This could include some tips/heuristics to help first-time customer define a scalable, performant schema, including:
- recommending data types (e.g. date detection from string)
- bucketing options for time-series
- detecting unique field for reuse as _id field
- shorter field names
- JSON Schema
toString:
Studio3T have quite an advanced [SQL to MongoDB Migration|https://studio3t.com/knowledge-base/articles/sql-to-mongodb-migration/#introduction] wizard. It seems to be able to connect to any [SQL Server|https://studio3t.com/knowledge-base/articles/sql-to-mongodb-migration/#connect-to-a-sql-server] and includes some UI for defining relationships between tables to create structured documents with arrays etc during the import process.

Since we don't have any official/home-grown tools for transforming SQL data during import, I think Compass would be a great place to introduce such a feature.

This could include some tips/heuristics to help first-time customers define a scalable, performant schema, including:
 - recommending data types (e.g. date detection from string)
 - bucketing options for time-series
 - detecting unique field for reuse as _id field
 - shorter field names
 - JSON Schema
author: nicholas.cottrell

fromString:
h3. Compass 1.17.0

h3. Behavior:
The connection string generated for a replica set does not include the port on all hosts.

h3. Reproduction:
# Start two replica sets, one with all members listening on 27017 and one with all members on  27018
# Add both hosts to the server hostname list
# Add port 27018
# Authentication Type: LDAP
# Connect
# Connection will be to the 27017 node or you may receive an error indicating that replica sets do not match.

h3. Workaround:
Use a single host for your connection string or ensure that the node you want to connect to is running on the default port.
toString:
h3. Compass 1.17.0
h3. Behavior:

The connection string generated for a replica set does not include the port on all hosts.
h3. Reproduction:
 # Start two replica sets that each have two members, one with all members listening on 27017 and one with all members on 27018
 #* e.g. rs0 has two members: server0:27017 and server1:27017
 #* rs1: server0:27018 and server1:27018
 # Add both hosts to the server hostname list
 #* e.g. server0,server1
 # Add port 27018
 # Authentication Type: LDAP
 # Connect
 # Connection will be to the 27017 node or you may receive an error indicating that replica sets do not match.

h3. Workaround:

Use a single host for your connection string or ensure that the node you want to connect to is running on the default port.
author: kip.iwakiri

fromString:
Whitespace at the beginning or end of the username in the connection window will prevent a successful connection.  However, it is not obvious there is whitespace present in the UI.

Since copy/paste sometimes appends/prepends whitespace, we should consider trimming it from the beginning and end of the username on the connection dialog.
toString:
Whitespace at the beginning or end of the username in the connection window will prevent a successful connection.  However, it is not obvious there is whitespace present in the UI.

Since copy/paste sometimes appends/prepends whitespace, we should consider trimming it from the beginning and end of the username on the connection dialog.

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to duplicate an existing View
So that I don't need to start from scratch when I want to create a new, similar one

h3. Acceptance criteria
- In the sidebar, I have an entry point to duplicate a View
- When I click on the entry point to duplicate a View, I can specify the name for the new View and then the new View is created with the same aggregation pipeline that is behind the original View
- When the duplicate View is created, a new tab is opened pointing to the Documents view of the new View
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to duplicate an existing View
So that I don't need to start from scratch when I want to create a new, similar one

h3. Acceptance criteria
- In the sidebar, I have an entry point to duplicate a View
- When I click on the entry point to duplicate a View, I can specify the name for the new View and then the new View is created with the same aggregation pipeline that is behind the original View
- When the duplicate View is created, a new tab is opened pointing to the Documents view of the new View
- When the server returns errors (e.g., the user doesn't have the necessary permissions to create a new view), Compass needs to handle the errors nicely
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to edit a View (as in "edit the aggregation pipeline behind the View")
So that I can go and adjust the details if the documents I am seeing are not in the shape I expected them to be

h3. Acceptance criteria
- In the sidebar, I have an entry point to go and edit the aggregation behind each View
- In the main screen, when I am looking at a View, I have entry points to go and edit the aggregation behind the View
- When I go and edit the aggregation behind a View, I am editing it in the aggregation pipeline builder of the Collection or View the View I am editing is based on
- When I am done with editing the aggregation pipeline, I can update the View with the new pipeline

h3. Questions
- When a View has been updated, can we jump back to wherever the user was when they clicked on an entry point to editing the View?
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to edit a View (as in "edit the aggregation pipeline behind the View")
So that I can go and adjust the details if the documents I am seeing are not in the shape I expected them to be

h3. Acceptance criteria
- In the sidebar, I have an entry point to go and edit the aggregation behind each View
- In the main screen, when I am looking at a View, I have entry points to go and edit the aggregation behind the View
- When I go and edit the aggregation behind a View, I am editing it in the aggregation pipeline builder of the Collection or View the View I am editing is based on
- When I am done with editing the aggregation pipeline, I can update the View with the new pipeline
- When the server returns errors (e.g., the user doesn't have the necessary permissions to modify a View), Compass needs to handle the errors nicely

h3. Questions
- When a View has been updated, can we jump back to wherever the user was when they clicked on an entry point to editing the View?
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString: Iteration Dingo, Iteration Echidna, Iteration F
author: durran.jordan@10gen.com

fromString: Iteration Dingo, Iteration Echidna, Iteration Ferret
toString: Iteration Dingo, Iteration Echidna, Iteration G, Iteration Ferret
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
With this feature, we are artificially creating a concept that does not exist in the server: the ability to modify a view. Because this concept does not exist in the server, when we get the aggregation pipeline that is backing a View, the server does not give us the collation information (if it was set) so we cannot save it back and it gets lost.

Because there is not much we can do about it, let's just document the behavior.
author: massimiliano.marcon

author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to see the details of a View when I select it
So that I can easily understand that it is a View and I can see what collection it is based on

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I open a View in Compass, I can clearly see that I am actually looking at a View
- When I open a View in Compass, I can see what collection the View is based on
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to see the details of a View when I select it
So that I can:
- easily understand that it is a View and I can see what collection it is based on
- see the documents that are in the View and run queries and aggregations on top of it

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I open a View in Compass, I can clearly see that I am actually looking at a View
- When I open a View in Compass, I can see what collection the View is based on
- When I am building aggregations on top of a View, I want so see meaningful errors when I try to use [operators that are not supported on Views|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/db.createView]
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to see the details of a View when I select it
So that I can:
- easily understand that it is a View and I can see what collection it is based on
- see the documents that are in the View and run queries and aggregations on top of it

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I open a View in Compass, I can clearly see that I am actually looking at a View
- When I open a View in Compass, I can see what collection the View is based on
- When I open a View in Compass, I don't want to see N/A placeholders for the details we can't display (see screeenshot attached)
- When I am building aggregations on top of a View, I want so see meaningful errors when I try to use [operators that are not supported on Views|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/db.createView]

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to create a View from an aggregation pipeline
So that I can make sure my data is in the right shape to be used in my application or to create a chart from it.

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I am in the aggregation pipeline builder and I have written a valid aggregation, I want to be able to save it as a View and give it a name
- When an aggregation is saved as a View, it immediately appears in the sidebar
- When an aggregation is saved as a View and I open the Database screen, I can see the newly created View
- It is possible to create a View on top of another View
- When I am trying to create a new View with the same name of an existing View, I want to see a meaningful error message
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to create a View from an aggregation pipeline
So that I can make sure my data is in the right shape to be used in my application or to create a chart from it.

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I am in the aggregation pipeline builder and I have written a valid aggregation, I want to be able to save it as a View and give it a name
- When an aggregation is saved as a View, it immediately appears in the sidebar
- When an aggregation is saved as a View and I open the Database screen, I can see the newly created View
- It is possible to create a View on top of another View
- When I am trying to create a new View with the same name of an existing View, I want to see a meaningful error message
- When the View has been created, Compass will open the new View in the main screen (in a new tab, as soon as tabs are available)
author: massimiliano.marcon

toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to create a View from an aggregation pipeline
So that I can make sure my data is in the right shape to be used in my application or to create a chart from it.

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I am in the aggregation pipeline builder and I have written a valid aggregation, I want to be able to save it as a View and give it a name
- When the server is older than 3.4, Save as a View is hidden
- When an aggregation is saved as a View, it immediately appears in the sidebar
- When an aggregation is saved as a View and I open the Database screen, I can see the newly created View
- It is possible to create a View on top of another View
- When I am trying to create a new View with the same name of an existing View, I want to see a meaningful error message
- When the View has been created, Compass will open the new View in the main screen (in a new tab, as soon as tabs are available)
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to create a View from an aggregation pipeline
So that I can make sure my data is in the right shape to be used in my application or to create a chart from it.

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I am in the aggregation pipeline builder and I have written a valid aggregation, I want to be able to save it as a View and give it a name
- When the server is older than 3.4, Save as a View is hidden
- When an aggregation is saved as a View, it immediately appears in the sidebar
- When an aggregation is saved as a View and I open the Database screen, I can see the newly created View
- It is possible to create a View on top of another View
- When I am trying to create a new View with the same name of an existing View, I want to see a meaningful error message
- When the View has been created, Compass will open the new View in the main screen (in a new tab, as soon as tabs are available)
toString:
h3. User story
As a Compass user
I want to create a View from an aggregation pipeline
So that I can make sure my data is in the right shape to be used in my application or to create a chart from it.

h3. Acceptance criteria
- When I am in the aggregation pipeline builder and I have written a valid aggregation, I want to be able to save it as a View and give it a name
- When the server is older than 3.4, Save as a View is hidden
- When an aggregation is saved as a View, it immediately appears in the sidebar
- When an aggregation is saved as a View and I open the Database screen, I can see the newly created View
- It is possible to create a View on top of another View
- When I am trying to create a new View with the same name of an existing View, I want to see a meaningful error message
- When the server returns errors (e.g., the user doesn't have the necessary permissions to create a view), Compass needs to handle the errors nicely
- When the View has been created, Compass will open the new View in the main screen (in a new tab, as soon as tabs are available)
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
The heading row rendering needs to be fixed to stay in the correct location.
Technically the heading rows children have to be adjusted to behave just like the data columns as those are functioning correctly.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
In the list view, when expanding on a nested object, 

The row with column titles is overlapping the first column of the nested object with the column of the root object.

There fore the titles row and the content row are missmatching.

 

also the last column end up with no column heading.

 

See attached images for better understanding.

toString:
In the list view, when expanding on a nested object, 

The row with column titles is overlapping the first column of the nested object with the column of the root object.

There fore the titles row and the content row are missmatching.

 

also the last column end up with no column heading.

 
See attached images for better understanding.

---
The heading row rendering needs to be fixed to stay in the correct location.
Technically the heading rows children have to be adjusted to behave just like the data columns as those are functioning correctly.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
@max for your triage consideration [from Slack convo w/ @joy|https://mongodb.slack.com/archives/GDTJXPHD0/p1552063074008400]. Easy impl. Assume {{⌘}} below is {{ctrl}} on Windows.

- {{⌘+S}} Save current pipeline
- {{⇧+⌘+S}} Save As
- {{⇧+⌘+O}} to toggle Saved Pipeline List
- {{⌘+V}} Paste from Clipboard silently creates new (kinda like COMPASS-3086 if that doesn't work out. Same state requirements here. Shortcut would be easier impl. )
- {{⌘+N}} New pipeline
- {{⇧⌘+N}} Shows modal with text input (new pipeline from text)

toString:
@max for your triage consideration [from Slack convo w/ @joy|https://mongodb.slack.com/archives/GDTJXPHD0/p1552063074008400]. Easy impl. Assume {{⌘}} below is {{ctrl}} on Windows and only listening for these when your on the {{Aggregations}} tab.

- {{⌘+S}} Save current pipeline (/)
- {{⇧+⌘+S}} Save As (/)
- {{⇧+⌘+O}} to toggle Saved Pipeline List (/)
- {{⌘+V}} Paste from Clipboard silently creates new (kinda like COMPASS-3086 if that doesn't work out. Same state requirements here. Shortcut would be easier impl. ) -> here we'd need confirmation, I may do it by mistake and overwrite the current aggregation. That would upset me. (x)
- {{⌘C + ⌘}} clone current pipeline -> what if it's not saved? this does nothing?
- {{⌘+N}} New pipeline (x) that shortcut is taken for a new Compass window and I would not change it as it is a pretty common shortcut
- {{⇧⌘+N}} Shows modal with text input (new pipeline from text) (/)

toString: This issue is related to SERVER-23656
author: massimiliano.marcon

from: The Server is introducing a new $$NOW system variable for this exact use case (SERVER-23656). We prefer to not do this in Compass as it introduces complexity when exporting the aggregation to different languages and also to avoid confusion on whether the comparison is done agains the local machine's time or the server's time.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
OS: Debian Testing
Behavior: Compass is stuck on the "Loading..." screen.

Docker container to reproduce the problem (tricky to run on a Mac): https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/beta/MongoDB-Compass

Screenshots attached.

* console is empty
* connect creates another window with the same behaviour
* Disconnect does nothing
* "If I start from the command line (not docker this time - directly on my host PC) I have this. So I guess the electron version is still a problem in here."

toString:
OS: Debian Testing
 Behavior: Compass is stuck on the "Loading..." screen.

Docker container to reproduce the problem (tricky to run on a Mac):

[https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/broken/MongoDB-Compass|https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/beta/MongoDB-Compass]

The broken branch is using debian:testing image.

The master and the beta branch are both using Ubuntu 16.04 and respectively Compass 1.17.0 (current stable) and 1.18.0-beta3 and only the stable version works as expected within the same environment. To verify that, you can run this command: `git diff master..beta `

[https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/master/MongoDB-Compass|https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/beta/MongoDB-Compass]

[https://github.com/MaBeuLux88/docker/tree/beta/MongoDB-Compass]

Screenshots attached.
 * console is empty
 * connect creates another window with the same behaviour
 * Disconnect does nothing
 * "If I start from the command line (not docker this time - directly on my host PC) I have this. So I guess the electron version is still a problem in here."

Reported by [~maxime.beugnet]
author: maxime.beugnet

from: A comment with security level 'Developers' was removed.
author: lucas.hrabovsky

toString:
Moves from inline to modal

- {{↵}} in modal to save
- {{Save}} on an unsaved pipeline brings up modal to specify a name
- {{Save}} on an existing saved pipeline just saves
- {{Save As...}} Enter new name {{➡️}} clone current pipeline
- If canceling from {{Save As...}} the current pipeline is not cloned
- {{Save As...}} from an unsaved pipeline should instead go to {{Save}}
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString:
In testing, it appears that the CSV export only includes the document fields found in the "first" document (natural order?) in the collection.  This is true even after performing a schema analysis that does find all fields in the collection's documents.

Reviewing the exported CSV file, it appears that columns (variables) are missing.
toString:
In testing, it appears that the CSV export only includes the document fields found in the "first" document (natural order?) in the collection.  This is true even after performing a schema analysis that does find all fields in the collection's documents.

Reviewing the exported CSV file, it appears that columns (variables) are missing.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
The timezone used to display a date field changes from UTC to the local desktop timezone in Compass 1.16.3 when the user edits the document on the Documents tab.

Compass should render dates:
* with a consistent timezone that is
* displayed (i.e. ISO, -0500) and
* configurable.
toString:
The timezone used to display a date field changes from UTC to the local desktop timezone in Compass 1.16.3 when the user edits the document on the Documents tab.

Compass should render dates:
* with a consistent timezone that is
* displayed (i.e. ISO, -0500) and
* configurable.
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: SchemaParser::new() should accept an option to handle semantic types. setting this to Some should allow for parsing of an email "type" and a geojson "type" along with the regular bson types.
toString:
SchemaParser::new() should accept an option to handle semantic types. setting this to Some should allow for parsing of an email "type" and a geojson "type" along with the regular bson types.

should look for crates that could do the geojson check for us; email should be a rather straight forward regex.
author: irina.shestak

toString:
In the Agg Builder warning messages, we currently use #f5f6f7 as the text color which is a bit hard to read. The same warning banner will be used in Schema Validation. 

Let's update to #ffffff to also match the yellow banner in Documents tab.

toString:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1. Run a query in Compass
2. Open the "..." menu next to the query bar and select Toggle Query History: [https://monosnap.com/file/YFyzw2thxuInuUCgnlKDZyOAtOZUup]
3. Select the RECENT heading to view recent queries and "star" one to favorite it
4. Type in a name for the query under FAVORITES, and hit ENTER to save the query – this causes Compass to go blank. If you click the SAVE button manually, the favorite saves without issue.
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
From COMPASS-3396 

A simple debug of what SDAM events we're seeing and when would be a quick win for cases like this.
toString:
From COMPASS-3396 

A simple debug of what SDAM events we're seeing and when would be a quick win for cases like this. We already listen for them in data-service but we don't really do anything with most (some are for deployment awareness etc.)

h4. Notes

* [sdam_viz script in the node driver|https://github.com/mongodb/node-mongodb-native/blob/master/test/tools/sdam_viz] for events and how/what to diff.
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString:
A simple debug of what SDAM events we're seeing and when would be a quick win for cases like this. We already listen for them in data-service but we don't really do anything with most (some are for deployment awareness etc.)

h4. Notes

* [sdam_viz script in the node driver|https://github.com/mongodb/node-mongodb-native/blob/master/test/tools/sdam_viz] for events and how/what to diff.
toString:
A simple debug of what SDAM events we're seeing and when would be a quick win for cases like this. We already listen for them in data-service but we don't really do anything with most (some are for deployment awareness etc.) Simply using {debug()} within event listeners would suffice.

h4. Notes

* [sdam_viz script in the node driver|https://github.com/mongodb/node-mongodb-native/blob/master/test/tools/sdam_viz] for events and how/what to diff.
author: lucas.hrabovsky
