fromString:
The [BSON spec|http://bsonspec.org/spec.html] includes support for UUID values, also known as GUID values.

The format of UUID values are defined in [rfc4122.txt|https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt].  For example,

{{f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6}}

Customers would like to work with UUID/GUID values in Compass as a fully supported data type, including search support in the RFC layout, ability to create new document fields of type UUID and the ability to edit UUID values in existing documents.

The mongo shell [documentation|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/UUID/] provides this example:

{{UUID("3b241101-e2bb-4255-8caf-4136c566a962")}}

Example Intercom conversations:
https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/534935/conversations/14679713485
https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/unassigned/conversations/15420803809
author: craig.homa

toString: This issue is related to COMPASS-1083
author: massimiliano.marcon

fromString:
This task is intended to follow-up on COMPASS-2707 in order to:
# Validate further that a pipeline builder UI constructed of horizontal stages is more promising than the current design where stages are constructed vertically
# Understand better whether a horizontally scrolling pipeline builder UI is useable enough to overcome the shortcomings of a pipeline builder UI constructed of vertical stages.

We will be creating three prototypes:
# A basic version of the current design, with visuals to march wireframes of other prototypes (link TBD)
# A pipeline builder of horizontal stages using browser native horizontal scrolling (link TBD)
# A pipeline builder of horizontal stages using javascript carousel horizontal scrolling (link TBD)

Test to be conducted:
* Script (TBD)
* Results (TBD)

cc [~durran.jordan]
toString:

We will be creating three prototypes:
# A basic version of the [current design|https://mongodb.invisionapp.com/share/JXFUOHGNFUM#/279129025_00], with visuals to match wireframes style of other prototypes (link TBD)
# A pipeline builder of horizontal stages using browser native horizontal scrolling (link TBD)
# A pipeline builder of horizontal stages using javascript carousel horizontal scrolling (link TBD)

Test to be conducted:

* Results (TBD)

cc [~durran.jordan]
author: fred.truman

Request in Intercom.

> I'd like just to know if it's possible to start Compass connecting to a specific MongoDB passing a name of my favourites by args from command line


Makes perfect sense for larger environments where other tools are in use and there might be 100 or more deployments present.


Possible Epic: "Remove Friction"
https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/COMPASS-2280

fromString:
We should throw our own errors that give the most helpful message possible. 

(Not the same as providing semantic checking for the input code. This ticket is just to define the error class so we can throw errors if the tree is malformed, the types don't match, etc. There will be a separate ticket, that depends on this one, for going through and type checking or limiting input to  making JSON objects).
toString:
We should throw our own errors that give the most helpful message possible. 

(Not the same as providing semantic checking for the input code. This ticket is just to define the error class so we can throw errors if the tree is malformed, the types don't match, etc. There will be a [separate ticket|https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/COMPASS-2614], that depends on this one, for going through and type checking or limiting input to  making JSON objects).
author: anna.herlihy@10gen.com

fromString:
I'm filing this now so as to ensure there is awareness within the Compass team about this concept, whether or not this can be implemented over the medium term (hopefully it can).

As of the MongoDB 4.0 release, we will have easy access to a free monitoring embedded in the server. The mongo shell will encourage community users to enable sending monitoring  to MongoDB's Free Monitoring Cloud, which will then return a dedicated cloud URL for them to navigate to, in order to see their free monitoring.

Ideally in line with the MongoDB 4.0 release, or soon after, MongoDB Compass would do the same when connecting to MongoDB community
- e.g. it should prompt users to enable access to our free monitoring cloud
- after enabling it should show the user their dedicated monitoring URL

For more information, see the "blog at time of release" style product description document:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1p44xcmzPnb4srYyVc0MF-Uhf4cG_RksIfEGXbKI2h8I/edit

And see the ongoing Server/Shell Scope document:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KuwqMLSIMFaYGyN0BBJFZkkvi86woFZYKpgGzGVLrts/edit?disco=AAAABqzZRjg&ts=5a9725b9

The scope of this project has rapidly been solidifying over the last few weeks, hence filing this now.
toString:
I'm filing this now so as to ensure there is awareness within the Compass team about this concept, whether or not this can be implemented over the medium term (hopefully it can).

As of the MongoDB 4.0 release, we will have easy access to a free monitoring embedded in the server. The mongo shell will encourage community users to enable sending monitoring  to MongoDB's Free Monitoring Cloud, which will then return a dedicated cloud URL for them to navigate to, in order to see their free monitoring.

Ideally in line with the MongoDB 4.0 release, or soon after, MongoDB Compass would do the same when connecting to MongoDB community
- e.g. it should prompt users to enable access to our free monitoring cloud
- after enabling it should show the user their dedicated monitoring URL

The scope of this project has rapidly been solidifying over the last few weeks, hence filing this now.
author: craig.homa

toString: As a DBA I need to export and import extensive connection favorites between channels, users and systems
author: brian.blevins

fromString:
Customer moved from beta channel to stable channel.

> upgrade of Compass wipes out all existing connection settings. Please retain existing connections or provide export/import functionality. This is a huge issue when you have dozens of servers/replicasets.

https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/all/conversations/14761374533

Presumably, this would not include passwords/credentials.  Or possibly would depend on whether sensitive information is stored in favorites.

https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/COMPASS-2556
toString:

fromString:
Intercom conversation
https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/inbox/unassigned/conversations/14739190136


> Hi. For the Compass saved "Favorites", is it possible to save the Fav specifically without the LDAP Password and the without the Client Key Password? Instead leave them blank as a favorite, so I can then enter them each time logging in?

> The reason is if the MongoDb has PHI data, and if I lost my computer, a hacker could not just click to open and gain immediate access. Thank you. Michael Kranz - Walgreens

toString: Community: Remove ability to toggle usage stats and auto updates on/off
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString: There appears to be a regression in CC 1.11.2: the privacy settings are visable, toggleable and can be accessed from the Help->Privacy menu.
toString:
There appears to be a regression in CC 1.11.2: the privacy settings are visable, toggleable and can be accessed from the Help->Privacy menu. 

Updated description:
- We want to force users to provide usage stats and force them to have auto-updates so they are always running the latest version. Let's remove those options from the privacy menu.

fromString:
Let's get on the latest version of React (16.2.0)

Acceptance Criteria:
- Update hadron-app peer dependencies to React 16.2.0
- Update the compass-plugin template to use React 16.2.0
- Update compass to depend on React 16.2.0.
- Update all the Compass plugins to React 16.2.0
- Bump the Compass plugin api version to 2.0.0.
- Inform Tomer & Pavel of the changes and that they need to upgrade their plugins.
toString:
Let's get on the latest version of React (16.3.2)

Acceptance Criteria:
- Update hadron-app peer dependencies to React 16.3.2
- Update the compass-plugin template to use React 16.3.2
- Update compass to depend on React 16.3.2.
- Update all the Compass plugins to React 16.3.2
- Bump the Compass plugin api version to 2.0.0.
- Upgrade Enzyme in all Plugins to 3.3.0.
- Inform Tomer & Pavel of the changes and that they need to upgrade their plugins.
author: durran.jordan@10gen.com

toString:
*Product Acceptance Criteria*
- A visual representation in the UI indicating that the query is exportable as various language syntaxes
- Filter, skip, project and limit should be included in the export
- Aggregation pipeline syntax as well as regular find syntax should be exportable
- No need to include the method calls to the generated method (method only is fine)
- Should have an option to include generated connection information.
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString: Persist favorites and recent connections to disk
toString: As a user I want to persist favorites and recent connections to somewhere other than local storage
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

toString: This issue is related to COMPASS-2052
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString:
This is in relation to a support case opened for the *Citigroup - Admin* project. Compass does not retain favorites and recent connection information. 

The customer indicates that they can create connections fine and also save these as favorites. When they restart Compass they can see both their recent connections and saved favourites in the left hand panel as expected.

However, when they log out of their Windows server and back in again their favorites and recent connections do not persist. I understand that these are saved in {{localStorage}} and they are not stored as file on disk at present. 

Would it be possible to store these customisations as file on disk in a future release. The inability to do so is causing considerable annoyance for Citigroup. Customer quote:

{quote}
I definitely think favourite and recent connections should be persistently stored by Compass in order for this feature to be useful and to be consistent with how other tools (such as database browsers) handle this functionality.

The Citi Engineering team is heavily pushing Compass to be the standard MongoDB data analysis/manipulation GUI tool used in the bank and this lack of persistence is proving to be very annoying to users.
{quote}
toString:
The customer indicates that they can create connections fine and also save these as favorites. When they restart Compass they can see both their recent connections and saved favourites in the left hand panel as expected.

However, when they log out of their Windows server and back in again their favorites and recent connections do not persist. I understand that these are saved in {{localStorage}} and they are not stored as file on disk at present.
author: craig.homa

author: brian.blevins

fromString:
Hi team,

It appears that when both "Server and Client Validation" and SSH Tunnel are configured, COMPASS will not send the client SSL certificate. 
I am able to connect via either SSH Tunnel or  "Server and Client Validation" (change mongod config according, of course).

- How to reproduce
-- Start {{mognod}} with the following config
{code:theme=Emacs|language=text}
net:
  port: 37017
  ssl:
    mode: "requireSSL"
    PEMKeyFile: "/home/ec2-user/ssl-test/server.pem"
    CAFile: "/home/ec2-user/ssl-test/chain.crt"
{code}
-- Connect from COMPASS using the options shown in the screenshot
   !sceenshot.png|thumbnail!

- Observations
-- I am able to connect to the mongod via SSH tunnel in command line:
--- In one terminal, create an SSH tunnel using this command: 
{code:theme=Emacs|language=text}
ssh ec2-13-210-197-134.ap-southeast-2.compute.amazonaws.com -L 37000:localhost:37017
{code}

--- In another terminal, connect to the mongod using the following mongo shell command:
{code:theme=Emacs|language=text}
mongo --port 37000 -ssl --sslCAFile ~/projects/ssl-test/chain.crt  --sslPEMKeyFile ~/projects/ssl-test/client.pem
{code}

-- When COMPASS tries to connect to the mongod, the mongod prints the following error message:
{code:theme=Emacs|language=text}
E NETWORK  [conn4] no SSL certificate provided by peer; connection rejected
{code}
I can see the same error message if I connect to the mongod instance via mongo shell but does not specify {{sslPEMKeyFile}}:
{code:theme=Emacs|language=text}
mongo --port 37000 -ssl --sslCAFile ~/projects/ssl-test/chain.crt
{code}

Therefore, I suspect that, somehow, when SSH Tunnel is enabled, the {{sslPEMKeyFile}} option is missed.

If any addition information needed, please let me know.

Regards,
Lungang
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString:
_The following is a request from a prospect who likely Compass but wants to see more feedback on user-error._

The query builder (filter) shows when the query is malformed but it doesn't give any indication as to why. Having a syntax checker and/or highlighting the likely error would be helpful (mismatched brackets, invalid key name, etc)

This would also apply to other planned features such as the aggregation framework query builder.
toString: The query builder (filter) shows when the query is malformed but it doesn't give any indication as to why. Having a syntax checker and/or highlighting the likely error would be helpful (mismatched brackets, invalid key name, etc)

fromString: No feedback for long running queries
toString: As a user I would like visual feedback when executing queries
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString: In Compass (all versions up to 1.10.1.0) long running queries give no feedback when running or when completed. As a result you have to spot the number of results changing to determine if a query is complete. I have attached a screen capture demonstrating this. Sorry about the background noise on the video. I was in an airport lounge :-)
toString:
As a user I would like visual feedback when executing queries so that I can tell that the operation was sent to the server and is currently in progress (remove uncertainty). 

From Joe:

In Compass (all versions up to 1.10.1.0) long running queries give no feedback when running or when completed. As a result you have to spot the number of results changing to determine if a query is complete. I have attached a screen capture demonstrating this. Sorry about the background noise on the video. I was in an airport lounge :-)
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString:
As a user I want to be informed about what plugins are trying to do and either authorize or deny those actions, in order to control the security of my Compass instance.

Acceptance Criteria:
User is prompted to authorize a plugin to:
- Access the database
- Access the network via any protocol
- Access the filesystem (read-only)
- Access connection details
If the user clicks "no", then the plugin will not be loaded.
If the user clicks "yes", then the plugin will be allowed to access those items in the list.
toString:
As a user I want to be informed about what plugins are trying to do and either authorize or deny those actions, in order to control the security of my Compass instance.

h5. Acceptance Criteria

User is prompted to authorize a plugin to:
- Access the database
- Access the network via any protocol
- Access the filesystem (read-only)
- Access connection details
If the user clicks "no", then the plugin will not be loaded.
If the user clicks "yes", then the plugin will be allowed to access those items in the list.
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString: As a user with limited permissions (read-only on a specific collection) I want to specify the collection to access when providing my connection details
toString: As a user with limited permissions (read-only on a specific collection) I want to view which collections I have access to and specify the collection to access when providing my connection details
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString:
Currently if a user has read access to a database, we can use this user to check all the collections in the database using Compass.

However, if the user has read access to just a collection in a database, currently there is no way to use this user to view the data in this collection in Compass. It would be nice if Compass allow us to enter the collection name, so that we can view the data in this collection.
toString:
*Problem description*
Users with collection-level access are unable to browse through the collections that they are authorized to access in Compass.

*Product acceptance criteria*
- Make use of the userInfo command with showPriveledges:true to enable enumerate which namespaces a user has access on.
- Display this list in the sidebar
- Display this list in the namespace "homescreen"
- The user should be able to click on a displayed namespace.
- The user should be taken to the normal "Compass experience" after selecting a namespace.
author: sam.weaver@10gen.com

fromString:
While OSX version of Compass is capable to returning meaningful SSL-related error messages, this ability is lacking in the Windows version.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with invalid CA
toString:
While OSX version of Compass is capable to returning meaningful SSL-related error messages, this ability is lacking in the Windows version.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with invalid CA. On OSX the error message says "Invalid or missing certificate" while on Windows, it's a generic "Could not connect message ..."
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:
While OSX version of Compass is capable to returning meaningful SSL-related error messages, this ability is lacking in the Windows version.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with invalid CA. On OSX the error message says "Invalid or missing certificate" while on Windows, it's a generic "Could not connect message ..."
toString:
While OSX version of Compass is capable to returning meaningful SSL-related error messages, this ability is lacking in the Windows version.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with invalid CA. On OSX the error message says "Invalid or missing certificate" while on Windows, it's a generic "Could not connect message ..."

Observed with 1.3-beta, 1.2 is returning proper message.
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString: SSL-related errors are not reported properly on Windows
toString: SSL-related errors are not reported properly on Compass 1.3-beta.3
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:
While OSX version of Compass is capable to returning meaningful SSL-related error messages, this ability is lacking in the Windows version.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with invalid CA. On OSX the error message says "Invalid or missing certificate" while on Windows, it's a generic "Could not connect message ..."

Observed with 1.3-beta, 1.2 is returning proper message.
toString:
This seems to be an issue with 1.3-beta version only. Applies to both Windows and OSX.

Consider the example in the attached screenshots - they show an attempt to connect with an invalid CA file. On 1.2 the error message says "Invalid or missing certificate" while on 1.3-beta, it's a generic "Could not connect message ..."
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

toString: This issue is related to HELP-9903
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:
At present (judging by the 1.3beta) Compass does not provide the same set of SSL-related options as {{mongo}} shell. For instance:
- There is no way to specify CRL ({{"--sslCRLFile"}} in shell)
- There is no way to disable hostname validation ({{"--sslAllowInvalidHostnames"}})
- Analogues of {{"--sslAllowInvalidCertificates"}} - note it's not the same as "Unvalidated" SSL connection. That option allows the client (e.g. shell) to present it's own certificate to the server, even if we accept that validation of the server's certificate can fail. The "Unvalidated" option does _not_ allow client to present its certificate.

Essentially, without these options the amount of SSL-related use cases supported by Compass is less than the use cases supported by the shell.

FWIW Even Robomongo does more than Compass: http://blog.robomongo.org/robomongo-rc10/
toString:
At present (judging by the 1.3beta) Compass does not provide the same set of SSL-related options as {{mongo}} shell. For instance:
- There is no way to specify CRL ({{"--sslCRLFile"}} in shell)
- There is no way to disable hostname validation ({{"--sslAllowInvalidHostnames"}})
- No analogue of {{"--sslAllowInvalidCertificates"}} - note it's not the same as "Unvalidated" SSL connection. That option allows the client (e.g. shell) to present it's own certificate to the server, even if we accept that validation of the server's certificate can fail. The "Unvalidated" option does _not_ allow client to present its certificate.

Essentially, without these options the amount of SSL-related use cases supported by Compass is less than the use cases supported by the shell.

FWIW Even Robomongo does more than Compass: http://blog.robomongo.org/robomongo-rc10/

toString:
At present (judging by the 1.3beta) Compass does not provide the same set of SSL-related options as {{mongo}} shell. For instance:
- There is no way to specify CRL ({{"--sslCRLFile"}} in shell)
- There is no way to disable hostname validation ({{"--sslAllowInvalidHostnames"}})
- No analogue of {{"--sslAllowInvalidCertificates"}} - note it's not the same as "Unvalidated" SSL connection. That option (in combination with others) allows the client (e.g. shell) to present it's own certificate to the server, even if we accept that validation of the server's certificate can fail. The "Unvalidated" option does _not_ allow client to present its certificate.

Essentially, without these options the amount of SSL-related use cases supported by Compass is less than the use cases supported by the shell.

FWIW Even Robomongo does more than Compass: http://blog.robomongo.org/robomongo-rc10/
author: dmitry.ryabtsev

fromString:
At present (judging by the 1.3beta) Compass does not provide the same set of SSL-related options as {{mongo}} shell. For instance:
- There is no way to specify CRL ({{"--sslCRLFile"}} in shell)
- There is no way to disable hostname validation ({{"--sslAllowInvalidHostnames"}})
- No analogue of {{"--sslAllowInvalidCertificates"}} - note it's not the same as "Unvalidated" SSL connection. That option (in combination with others) allows the client (e.g. shell) to present it's own certificate to the server, even if we accept that validation of the server's certificate can fail. The "Unvalidated" option does _not_ allow client to present its certificate.

Essentially, without these options the amount of SSL-related use cases supported by Compass is less than the use cases supported by the shell.

FWIW Even Robomongo does more than Compass: http://blog.robomongo.org/robomongo-rc10/
toString:
At present (judging by the 1.3beta) Compass does not provide the same set of SSL-related options as {{mongo}} shell. For instance:
- There is no way to specify CRL ({{"--sslCRLFile"}} in shell)
- There is no way to disable hostname validation ({{"--sslAllowInvalidHostnames"}})
- No analogue of {{"--sslAllowInvalidCertificates"}} - note it's not the same as "Unvalidated" SSL connection. That option (in combination with others) allows the client (e.g. shell) to present it's own certificate to the server, even if we accept that validation of the server's certificate can fail. The "Unvalidated" option does _not_ allow client to present its certificate.

Essentially, without these options the amount of SSL-related use cases supported by Compass is less than the amount of use cases supported by the shell.

FWIW Even Robomongo does more than Compass: http://blog.robomongo.org/robomongo-rc10/

fromString: Mechanism allowing unsophisticated users to provide a log file for technical services review
toString: Mechanism allowing users to provide a log file for technical services review
author: brian.blevins

fromString:
Although I thought this ticket was already present, various searches failed to find it.

Some unsophisticated customers have trouble with DevTools, particularly the part about selecting and exporting the contents of the "Console".

In order to expedite and simplify the support experience for customers, provide a mechanism that supports uploading a log file from Compass.  Possibilities include:
- add a new menu item labelled "Save Log File"
- add a new menu option labelled "Enable Debugging" (with the log file written to a known location)

The content of the log file would include at a minimum everything present in the DevTools [Console] tab.

Instructions from support should mention enabling debugging (if necessary), reproducing the issue and then saving or uploading the log file...

fromString:
h4. Goals

* A better understanding of the [CollectionsStore before all hook|https://github.com/10gen/compass/blob/f05b3ac/test/unit/collections.store.test.js#L18-L20] within the Compass unit test suite, e.g. How does the mock data service work?
* An estimate or probability - How likely it is to hit the 2000ms time limit?
* An explanation of how the 2000ms (or more) of time is spent
* Recommendations or proof-of-concepts which may resolve this issue

If time allows, PR and fix this test issue, if not, create a follow up ticket with any proposed future work.

As this ticket is a spike and focused on exploring - ideas are always welcome :)

h4. List of known failed builds

https://travis-ci.com/10gen/compass/jobs/93094619

As noted on COMPASS-2159, Travis build failures usually require the developer to manually retry the build, which as technical debt slows down the team's capacity to deliver new features and bug fixes.

In COMPASS-1217, in order to unblock CI and other tickets in Compass, this was pinned to the known good {{v1.0.0-rc.5}} version.
toString:
react-select recently released several new release candidates:

https://github.com/JedWatson/react-select/blob/master/HISTORY.md#v100-rc10--2017-09-13

In COMPASS-1217, in order to unblock CI and other tickets in Compass, this was pinned to the known good {{v1.0.0-rc.5}} version.

Acceptance criteria:

* Fix issue by bumping to latest version of react-select, or creating an upstream issue and working with the author to resolve
* Propagate fix into [document-validation|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation/] plugin (and bump in Compass)
* Propagate fix into Compass (Indexes Tab, or plugin if it has been plugin-ified)

fromString: As an Ops team member I want to script installs of Compass across many machines so I can deploy Compass on laptops of new employees (install widely across my organization).
toString:
As an Ops team member I want to script installs of Compass across many machines so I can deploy Compass on laptops of new employees (install widely across my organization).

*Product Acceptance Criteria*
- A working MSI installer (for the same platforms that we have .exe's for)
- MSI installer is signed by MongoDB as the publisher
- MSI installer should allow user to choose installation directory for Compass
- MSI installer should allow user to choose an installation directory for preferences and favorites
- Must support a "quiet" installation and output the log to a specified location.

fromString:
[Intercom Pain Point|https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/respond/inbox/conversation/11065521614]

Currently, pressing the refresh button in the query action bar will refresh the count in the message "Query returned X documents". However, pressing the refresh button will not update the top right collection stats.

This is problematic since the user can see two conflicting numbers concerning the total document count in a collection. Let's say there are 5 documents in the collection view. A user adds 5 more documents and presses refresh. They will see:
# "Query returned 10 documents" in the query action bar _and_
# Documents 5 in the top right collection stats

We should change the query bar refresh button to also update aggregate collection stats.
toString:
[Intercom Pain Point|https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/respond/inbox/conversation/11065521614]

Currently, pressing the refresh button in the query action bar will refresh the count in the message "Query returned X documents". However, pressing the refresh button will not update the top right collection stats.

This is problematic since the user can see two conflicting numbers concerning the total document count in a collection. Let's say there are 5 documents in the collection view. A user adds 5 more documents and presses refresh. They will see:
# "Query returned 10 documents" in the query action bar _and_
# Documents 5 in the top right collection stats

We should change the query bar refresh button to also update aggregate collection stats. This can be done by having the collection-stats store listen to the [refreshDocuments|https://github.com/10gen/compass-crud/blob/8b0bda4857ec9c75e6ba124f2ae7bd9221521c46/src/actions/index.js#L11] action in Crud plugin. Very similar to how it currently listens to [documentRemoved |https://github.com/10gen/compass/blob/c445781a630e66ad40736028bb783f9a76aaabff/src/internal-plugins/collection-stats/lib/store/index.js#L15] action.

Acceptance criteria:
* listen to refreshDocuments action in collection stats store and call {{loadCollectionStats}}
* add unit tests to show that appropriate calls are being made

fromString:
Add loading spinners in places known to be slow.

h4. Scenario
1. Visit data.mongodb.parts
2. Open mercedes.laps_31k_x_4k5 dataset, documents tab (Issue 1, Issue 2)
3. Click "Show 1000 more fields"
4. Double click on a field (after the first 25) to edit it, rendering the 1025 fields (or 2025 or more if the user went further) can take a long time (Issue 3)

h4. Issue 1
Fetching data from the server can take an unbounded amount of time (e.g. server never responds, server under a DDoS attack, rogue queries, etc).

!Thinking about remaining bottlenecks post disable chartView and COMPASS-1786.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 2
On different data sets, such as documents with ~500,000 fields (i.e. COMPASS-1766), Compass takes ~30 seconds or more to render, or crashes (COMPASS-1764). 

Would explicitly limiting Compass to say 100,000 fields with a message like "Compass cannot render documents with more than 100,000 fields" (and rendering the ObjectId field and delete button) seem reasonable?

For documents under 100k fields, is a loading spinner enough? (i.e. ~6 seconds, so should not need a progress bar?)

Example with 110,592 fields (48^3):

!perf.crazy_keys_48.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 3
As rendering can take a long time, the naive fix here is to let the user know it can take a long time with a spinner.

Aside: Longer term, getting field-based updates to work would allow the user to project only the fields they care about and then update just those fields, but there are no current plans to implement this.

Aside 2: This issue only affects edit mode, where the user has double-clicked on the specific field they wish to edit. Specifically clone, loading, cancel, update success and delete can all drop back to rendering just 25 fields, as they have no specific requirement to maintain the user's current context, and so are not affected.
toString:
Add loading spinners in places known to be slow.

h4. Scenario
1. Visit data.mongodb.parts
2. Open mercedes.laps_31k_x_4k5 dataset, documents tab (Issue 1, Issue 2)
3. Click "Show 1000 more fields"
4. Double click on a field (after the first 25) to edit it, rendering the 1025 fields (or 2025 or more if the user went further) can take a long time (Issue 3)

h4. Issue 1
Fetching data from the server can take an unbounded amount of time (e.g. server never responds, server under a DDoS attack, rogue queries, etc). Reuse the existing loading spinner for loading more documents.

!Thinking about remaining bottlenecks post disable chartView and COMPASS-1786.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 2
On different data sets, such as documents with ~500,000 fields (i.e. COMPASS-1766), Compass takes ~30 seconds or more to render, or crashes (COMPASS-1764). 

Would explicitly limiting Compass to say 100,000 fields with a message like "Compass cannot render documents with more than 100,000 fields" seem reasonable? Yes but only when the user gets down to the 100,001st field.

For documents under 100k fields, is a loading spinner enough? (i.e. ~6 seconds, so should not need a progress bar?)

Example with 110,592 fields (48^3):

!perf.crazy_keys_48.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 3
As rendering can take a long time, the naive fix here is to let the user know it can take a long time with a spinner.

Aside: Longer term, getting field-based updates to work would allow the user to project only the fields they care about and then update just those fields, but there are no current plans to implement this.

Aside 2: This issue only affects edit mode, where the user has double-clicked on the specific field they wish to edit. Specifically clone, loading, cancel, update success and delete can all drop back to rendering just 25 fields, as they have no specific requirement to maintain the user's current context, and so are not affected.
author: peter.schmidt

!Thinking about remaining bottlenecks post disable chartView and COMPASS-1786.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 2
On different data sets, such as documents with ~500,000 fields (i.e. COMPASS-1766), Compass takes ~30 seconds or more to render, or crashes (COMPASS-1764). 

Would explicitly limiting Compass to say 100,000 fields with a message like "Compass cannot render documents with more than 100,000 fields" seem reasonable? Yes but only when the user gets down to the 100,001st field.

For documents under 100k fields, is a loading spinner enough? (i.e. ~6 seconds, so should not need a progress bar?)

Example with 110,592 fields (48^3):

!perf.crazy_keys_48.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Issue 3
As rendering can take a long time, the naive fix here is to let the user know it can take a long time with a spinner.

Aside: Longer term, getting field-based updates to work would allow the user to project only the fields they care about and then update just those fields, but there are no current plans to implement this.

Aside 2: This issue only affects edit mode, where the user has double-clicked on the specific field they wish to edit. Specifically clone, loading, cancel, update success and delete can all drop back to rendering just 25 fields, as they have no specific requirement to maintain the user's current context, and so are not affected.

- Create mongodb-js/compass-explain-plan repo

- Move over Components

- Refactor Components to be Pure for use with Cloud

toString: Compass handles the crazy keys document series
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.
toString:
So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created with this relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144
80^3=512,000
author: peter.schmidt

toString:
So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created and imported into MongoDB with this script relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys and preliminary results:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144 (slow, ~5-10s)
80^3=512,000 (slow, ~30s)
96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000
author: peter.schmidt

toString:
So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created and imported into MongoDB with this script relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys and preliminary results:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144 (slow, ~5-10s)
80^3=512,000 (slow, ~30s)
96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000

Thus Compass, most likely in [mongodb-schema|https://github.com/mongodb-js/mongodb-schema], should stop scanning at about 100k fields in a document and report this Easter egg in the GUI (originally this was Issue 2 in COMPASS-1901).
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created and imported into MongoDB with this script relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys and preliminary results:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144 (slow, ~5-10s)
80^3=512,000 (slow, ~30s)
96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000

Thus Compass, most likely in [mongodb-schema|https://github.com/mongodb-js/mongodb-schema], should stop scanning at about 100k fields in a document and report this Easter egg in the GUI (originally this was Issue 2 in COMPASS-1901).

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

Then navigate to the perf.crazy_keys collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created and imported into MongoDB with this script relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys and preliminary results:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144 (slow, ~5-10s)
80^3=512,000 (slow, ~30s)
96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000

Thus Compass, most likely in [mongodb-schema|https://github.com/mongodb-js/mongodb-schema], should stop scanning at about 100k fields (configurable as other optimizations are found) in a document and report this Easter egg in the GUI (originally this was Issue 2 in COMPASS-1901).
author: peter.schmidt

96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000

Thus Compass, most likely in [mongodb-schema|https://github.com/mongodb-js/mongodb-schema], should stop scanning at about 100k fields (configurable as other optimizations are found) in a document and report this Easter egg in the GUI (originally this was Issue 2 in COMPASS-1901).
toString:
h4. Usage/steps to reproduce

{code}
# Generate the document
python3 mkbson.py 

# Import the document
mongorestore -d perf -c crazy_keys raw_crazy_keys.bson 
{code}

Then navigate to the {{perf.crazy_keys}} collection in Compass.

An extended set of documents can be created and imported into MongoDB with this script relatively easily, on my local machine I already have the following numbers of keys and preliminary results:
32^3=32,768
48^3=110,592 
64^3=262,144 (slow, ~5-10s)
80^3=512,000 (slow, ~30s)
96^3=884,736
140^3=2,744,000

h4. Proposed solution - cap at 100k fields

#intellectualhonesty - let the data drive your decision.

Thus Compass, most likely in [mongodb-schema|https://github.com/mongodb-js/mongodb-schema], should stop scanning at about 100k fields (configurable as other optimizations are found) in a document and report this Easter egg in the GUI (originally this was Issue 2 in COMPASS-1901).

h4. Acceptance criteria

* A mongoimport -able version of these documents, perhaps with easier to understand names like crazy_keys_512000.
* Cap field or schema processing at 100k fields, reporting this somehow, e.g. with properties such as "totalFieldCount", "analyzedFieldCount" (working titles to capture the semantic, change the syntax as needed).
* Message displaying this scenario, e.g. "100,000 fields limit reached, remaining N fields are not displayed"
* Appropriate unit tests

h4. Out of scope

* Anything in the schema/indexes/document validation tabs (such as the react-select dropdown to choose an index name), this is just about the Documents Tab.

h4. Background

So I let Friday afternoon get to me and challenged myself to create a document with ~2.7 million keys.

After about 3 minutes, Compass crashes. The mongo shell is still doing something in CPU-land after 8 minutes so far.

On different data sets, such as documents with ~500,000 fields (i.e. COMPASS-1766), Compass takes ~30 seconds or more to render, or crashes (COMPASS-1764). 

Would explicitly limiting Compass to say 100,000 fields with a message like "Compass cannot render documents with more than 100,000 fields" seem reasonable? Yes but only when the user gets down to the 100,001st field.

For documents under 100k fields, is a loading spinner enough? (i.e. ~6 seconds, so should not need a progress bar?). 

Proposed Solutions: Potentially push to the GPU? Otherwise just drop to {{Loading...}} text.
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
This request has been made many times, e.g. this intercom conversation: 
https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/respond/inbox/conversation/11245082354

Based on email discussion with Sam, Dana, Fred (see below), let's make the following changes:

Cmd-R (Ctrl-R on Windows/Linux) should reload data only. No app refresh. This should include: 

- always trigger a reload of the sidebar, and
- if the user is on the instance level databases view: refresh the list of databases
- if the user is on the database level collections view: refresh the list of collections
- if the user is on one of the collection level tabs, additionally execute the following action:
    - Documents tab: reload the documents (like the dedicated Refresh button)
    - Schema tab: execute a new schema sampling with the same query
    - Explain tab: execute a new explain plan with the same query
    - Indexes tab: refresh indexes
    - Document validation: reload validation rules
 

Cmd-Shift-R (Ctrl-Shift-R on Windows/Linux) should reload the app (behavior that is Cmd-R today).

Behavior:

- always trigger a reload of the sidebar, and
- if the user is on the instance level databases view: refresh the list of databases
- if the user is on the database level collections view: refresh the list of collections
- if the user is on one of the collection level tabs, additionally execute the following action:
-- Documents tab: reload the documents (like the dedicated Refresh button)
-- Schema tab: execute a new schema sampling with the same query
-- Explain tab: execute a new explain plan with the same query
-- Indexes tab: refresh indexes
-- Document validation: reload validation rules
 

Cmd-Shift-R (Ctrl-Shift-R on Windows/Linux) should reload the app (behavior that is Cmd-R today).
author: thomasr

toString:
This request has been made many times, e.g. this intercom conversation: 
https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/respond/inbox/conversation/11245082354

Based on email discussion with Sam, Dana, Fred (see below), let's make the following changes:

Cmd-R (Ctrl-R on Windows/Linux) should reload data only. No app refresh. 

Behavior:

- always trigger a reload of the sidebar, and
- if the user is on the instance level databases view: refresh the list of databases
- if the user is on the instance level RTSS view, reset the view
- if the user is on the database level collections view: refresh the list of collections
- if the user is on one of the collection level tabs, additionally execute the following action:
-- Documents tab: reload the documents (like the dedicated Refresh button)
-- Schema tab: execute a new schema sampling with the same query
-- Explain tab: execute a new explain plan with the same query
-- Indexes tab: refresh indexes
-- Document validation: reload validation rules
 

Cmd-Shift-R (Ctrl-Shift-R on Windows/Linux) should reload the app (behavior that is Cmd-R today).
author: thomasr

fromString:
Certain collections consumes a lot of memory during schema analysis as HELP-4695 indicates.

This ticket is to track and investigate the cause for higher memory consumption in some collections in mongodb-schema and if there are any potential solutions.

[Reproduction steps|https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/HELP-4695?focusedCommentId=1637700&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1637700] with mgenerate file attached to this ticket.
toString:
Certain collections consumes a lot of memory during schema analysis as HELP-4695 indicates.

This ticket is to track and investigate the cause for higher memory consumption in some collections in mongodb-schema and if there are any potential solutions.

[Reproduction steps|https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/HELP-4695?focusedCommentId=1637700&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1637700] with mgenerate file attached to this ticket.

Most relevant point in the above comment is "Compass is slower to analyze a 1000 document sample, versus 25000 documents (sample size 4%)."
author: satyendra.sinha

toString:
Certain collections consumes a lot of memory during schema analysis as HELP-4695 indicates.

This ticket is to track and investigate the cause for higher memory consumption in some collections and if there are any potential solutions.

[Reproduction steps|https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/HELP-4695?focusedCommentId=1637700&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1637700] with mgenerate file attached to this ticket.

Most relevant point in the above comment is "Compass is slower to analyze a 1000 document sample, versus 25000 documents (sample size 4%)." which implies that it is due to the two different collection samplers used in [mongodb-collection-sample|https://github.com/mongodb-js/collection-sample/blob/master/lib/index.js]
author: satyendra.sinha

fromString:
This process allows indexes to be built on the primary and secondaries of a replica set at different times, and indeed recommends building them on secondaries first:

https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/build-indexes-on-replica-sets/#build-indexes-on-all-secondaries

Thus if we allow connecting to a replica set, Compass will need a design and implementation for showing whether each listed index is present only on the primary, only on a specific secondary, or on all nodes in the discovered replica set.

From 2017 APAC Offsite, it is anecdotally quite common to build indexes only on secondaries, e.g. for analytics workloads.
toString:
This process allows indexes to be built on the primary and secondaries of a replica set at different times, and indeed recommends building them on secondaries first:

https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/build-indexes-on-replica-sets/#build-indexes-on-all-secondaries

Thus if we allow connecting to a replica set, Compass will need a design and implementation for showing whether each listed index is present only on the primary, only on a specific secondary, or on all nodes in the discovered replica set.

From 2017 APAC Offsite, it is anecdotally quite common to build indexes only on secondaries, e.g. for analytics workloads.

h2. ListIndexes node driver example

{code}
// Note: Not yet modified for readPreference or >1 connection proposals as example doesn't yet have distinct indexes
var { MongoClient } = require('mongodb')
MongoClient.connect('mongodb://admin:admin@cluster0-shard-00-00-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-01-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-02-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017/sam?ssl=true&replicaSet=Cluster0-shard-0&authSource=admin'
, (err, db) => {db.collection('sam').listIndexes().toArray((err, indexes) => {console.log(err, indexes);})})
{code}

h2. Proposal 1

Test whatever actually happens and just document it clearly e.g. info sprinkles or warning triangles.

h2. Proposal 2

Use [readPreference|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/read-preference/] to distinguish between primary and secondaries only.

h2. Proposal 3

Use (or create if necessary) additional standalone connections to listIndexes on each individual mongod.
author: peter.schmidt

fromString: View Indexes Tab should be display the different indexes on primaries and secondaries
toString: Can't see different indexes on primaries and secondaries
author: peter.schmidt

// Note: Not yet modified for readPreference or >1 connection proposals as example doesn't yet have distinct indexes
var { MongoClient } = require('mongodb')
MongoClient.connect('mongodb://admin:admin@cluster0-shard-00-00-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-01-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-02-4qowg.mongodb.net:27017/sam?ssl=true&replicaSet=Cluster0-shard-0&authSource=admin'
, (err, db) => {db.collection('sam').listIndexes().toArray((err, indexes) => {console.log(err, indexes);})})
{code}

h2. Proposal 1

Test whatever actually happens and just document it clearly e.g. info sprinkles or warning triangles.

h2. Proposal 2

Use [readPreference|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/read-preference/] to distinguish between primary and secondaries only.

h2. Proposal 3

Use (or create if necessary) additional standalone connections to listIndexes on each individual mongod.
toString:
This process allows indexes to be built on the primary and secondaries of a replica set at different times, and indeed recommends building them on secondaries first:

https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/build-indexes-on-replica-sets/#build-indexes-on-all-secondaries

From 2017 APAC Offsite, it is anecdotally quite common to build indexes only on secondaries, e.g. for analytics workloads.
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
If I {{npm start}} inside the [compass-document-validation|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation] repository then open the devtools, I do not get react+devtron tabs.

A [PoC exists|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation/commit/5bbf10971d8448a122703ca53bb40a963e518891], but it should be generalised.

Open questions

- Should it be coupled to {{NODE_ENV}} or always be loaded as part of being in the {{electron}} top-level directory of the plugin?
- Should the scope for this ticket be expanded to all plugins?
- Should the `electron` directory (or at least a subset of it such as the {{electron/main}} process handler?) be moved into a dependency so it can be reused across plugins? What work might need to be done to accomodate this?
toString:
If I {{npm start}} inside the [compass-document-validation|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation] repository then open the devtools, I do not get react+devtron tabs.

A [PoC exists|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation/commit/5bbf10971d8448a122703ca53bb40a963e518891], but it should be generalised. (It does not appear to be present in the [compass-plugin|https://github.com/mongodb-js/compass-plugin/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=devtron&type=] template at this time)

Open questions

- Should it be coupled to {{NODE_ENV}} or always be loaded as part of being in the {{electron}} top-level directory of the plugin?
- Should the scope for this ticket be expanded to all plugins?
- Should the `electron` directory (or at least a subset of it such as the {{electron/main}} process handler?) be moved into a dependency so it can be reused across plugins? What work might need to be done to accomodate this?
author: peter.schmidt

toString: Generalize "Show N more fields" to nested arrays and sub-fields

fromString:
We already limit the top-level fields to the first n (=20?) in the documents view and ask the user to confirm if they want to load more. 

This doesn't seem to be the case yet for array elements (and possibly also for nested sub-document fields). 

Attached is a dataset with a single document that demonstrates the performance issues.
toString:
We already limit the top-level fields to the first n (=20?) in the documents view and ask the user to confirm if they want to display more with the "Show N more fields" button. 

This doesn't seem to be the case yet for array elements (and possibly also for nested sub-document fields). 

Attached is a dataset with a single document that demonstrates the performance issues.
author: peter.schmidt

toString:
We already limit the top-level fields to the first n (=30) in the documents view and ask the user to confirm if they want to display more with the "Show N more fields" button. 

This doesn't seem to be the case yet for array elements or nested sub-document fields. 

Attached is a dataset with a single document that demonstrates the performance issues:
 [^large_array.json]

fromString:
Currently the Editable component resides in Doc Validation but it is a generic component that can be used throughout Compass. 

It will be pulled over to Compass after COMPASS-1303 is done. The work remaining is:
- Remove the Editable component from [Doc Validation|https://github.com/10gen/compass-document-validation] and use the version from Compass via the appRegistry lifecycle methods
- Remove any !important tags in the {{editable.less}} file as it shouldn't be required anymore.

Acceptance criteria:
- Make sure Doc Validation UI remains the same
- Make sure Charts UI remains the same

fromString:
Network bandwidth is traditionally measured in bits/second, either Kbps, Mbps or Gbps.

Additionally, the current real time server stats display network utilization as KByte/sec, even when this is in the hundreds of thousands of Kbyte/sec.

{{mongostat}} supports scaled units, however that may be disabled to aid in parsing the output.

Finally, the display indicates "KB", however it should be "KB/s" for the current configuration.  Of course, when scaled (changing) units are available in bits, then it should change accordingly:  Kb/s, Mb/s and Gb/s.
toString:
Network bandwidth is traditionally measured in bits/second, either Kbps, Mbps or Gbps.

Additionally, the current real time server stats display network utilization as KByte/sec, even when this is in the hundreds of thousands of Kbyte/sec.

{{mongostat}} supports scaled units, however that may be disabled to aid in parsing the output.

Finally, the display indicates "KB", however it should be "KB/s" for the current configuration.  Of course, when scaled (changing) units are available in bits, then it should change accordingly:  Kb/s, Mb/s and Gb/s.
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: Network statistics should have scaled units with bits/sec instead of bytes/sec
toString: Network statistics uses scaled units with bits/sec instead of bytes/sec
author: lucas.hrabovsky

{ IdentityId: NUUID("f785a41f-b35b-49f2-adb9-9d12f3cae50f") } supported by Robomongo,
 or { IdentityId: LUUID("f785a41f-b35b-49f2-adb9-9d12f3cae50f") }  or  { IdentityId: BinData(0, "taKIuIN6QYCcp4aHTCD7tw==") supported by Robomongo, 3T Studio, MongoBooster.

toString:
We added support for querying UUID types both via the querybar as well as in Aggregations.

Users can do that with queries such as {uuid: UUID('7f27133c-3086-46d0-861a-e76666ab974')}.

Additionally, UUIDs (binary type with subtype 4) are displayed in the documents tab and in the aggregation results as UUID('3b241101-e2bb-4255-8caf-4136c566a962').

fromString:
Currently Instance Fetching happens eagerly by pulling all the databases/collections together, which can cause the UI to hang the more namespaces there are (More database/collections).

Ideally it would be better if this fetching happens lazily or just-in-time. The goal of this ticket is to prevent fetching instances from blocking UI.
toString:
Currently Instance fetching happens eagerly by pulling all the databases/collections together (see [instance-model|https://github.com/mongodb-js/instance-model/blob/master/lib/fetch.js]), which can cause the UI to hang the more namespaces there are.

The goal of this ticket is to

- isolate the bottleneck of the instance fetching,
- improve the performance of the fetching,
- or prevent fetching instances from blocking UI, e.g. by fetching the details lazily or asynchronously
author: thomasr

fromString: Slow performance and UI irresponsive on collection with 1,000+ fields
toString: Slow performance and UI unresponsive on collection with 1,000+ fields
author: stennie

fromString:
Received a proposed schema/dat set for an IoT use case from a prospect. The document has 1,000+ fields and 36,000 docs in the data set. When trying to load into Compass, the schema analysis takes several minutes, and when completed, Compass becomes irresponsive, and my CPU starts to max out.

Even though the schema could be changed to use nested documents and arrays (that will be advised to the prospect) - our Compass product should perform properly.
toString:
Received a proposed schema/dat set for an IoT use case from a prospect. The document has 1,000+ fields and 36,000 docs in the data set. When trying to load into Compass, the schema analysis takes several minutes, and when completed, Compass becomes unresponsive, and my CPU starts to max out.

Even though the schema could be changed to use nested documents and arrays (that will be advised to the prospect) - our Compass product should perform properly.
author: stennie

fromString: Use skipTourAndNetworkOptin on functional tests and update readme
author: satyendra.sinha

fromString:
With merging COMPASS-857 each test is 'almost' independent of each other. What's remaining is to not having to rely on the launch tests run before running any of the other tests, which includes skipping the feature tour and selecting the network optin. A helper function that does this is already included in {{ /test/functional/support/helpers.js}}.

The goals of this ticket is:
- Use the {{skipTourAndNetworkOptin}} in every functional test except for the launch.test.js
- Update the readme to indicate that each of the functional tests can be run on it's own via mocha's {{-g}} flag e.g. {{npm test -- --functional -g '#schema'}}

fromString:
Schema view suffers from latency in the UI.

Connecting to data.parts and using the best buy collection. We need to fix the follow issues:

- When scrolling, the schema view hangs and is juttery. We should ensure that it is smooth to scroll the window up and down.
- When clicking on the collection, the screen takes a couple of seconds to react and product the analysis screen. We should ensure that there is a loading screen immediately.
- Tooltips take several seconds to appear. Tooltips should appear immediately.

- When clicking on the collection, the screen takes a couple of seconds to react and product the analysis screen. We should ensure that there is a loading screen immediately.
- Tooltips take several seconds to appear. Tooltips should appear immediately. (May be resolved by COMPASS-995)

*The purpose of this ticket is to use the performance tooling available in Electron devtools to identify current bottlenecks and create follow-up tickets for implementing those changes*.
toString:
Schema view suffers from latency in the UI.

Connecting to data.parts and using the best buy collection. We need to fix the follow issues:

- When scrolling, the schema view hangs and is juttery. We should ensure that it is smooth to scroll the window up and down.
- When clicking on the collection, the screen takes a couple of seconds to react and product the analysis screen. We should ensure that there is a loading screen immediately.
- Tooltips take several seconds to appear. Tooltips should appear immediately. (May be resolved by COMPASS-995)

*The purpose of this ticket is to use the performance tooling available in Electron devtools to identify current bottlenecks and create follow-up tickets for implementing those changes.*
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: Password field should not be mandatory in Compass when connecting to a Kerberos authenticated MongoDB deployment
toString: Spike: Research if/how Compass can be "kerberized"
author: thomasr

fromString:
Reported by Barclays (00430436).

When connecting to a Kerberos authenticated MongoDB deployment using Compass, we must supply the password from the Compass UI. Ideally, Compass should use the context of the logged in user and hence a password should not be needed unless a different context/user is needed to connect to the MongoDB deployment.
toString:

Ideally, Compass should use the context of the logged in user and hence a password should not be needed unless a different context/user is needed to connect to the MongoDB deployment.
author: thomasr

fromString:
Reported by Barclays (00430436).

When connecting to a Kerberos authenticated MongoDB deployment using Compass, we must supply the password from the Compass UI. Ideally, Compass should use the context of the logged in user and hence a password should not be needed unless a different context/user is needed to connect to the MongoDB deployment.
toString:
Reported by Barclays (00430436).

When connecting to a Kerberos authenticated MongoDB deployment using Compass, we must supply the password from the Compass UI. Ideally, Compass should use the context of the logged in user and hence a password should not be needed unless a different context/user is needed to connect to the MongoDB deployment.

This is how "kerberized" applications usually behave, and while the current implementation works, it's unusual and unexpected for users used to work in a kerberos environment.
author: thomasr

author: lucas.hrabovsky

toString: This issue is related to COMPASS-851
author: peter.schmidt

fromString: This issue has to be done before COMPASS-851
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
Provide a histogram of commonly slow queries since entering the performance tab or pressing PLAY.  Same as hottest queries but over time.  Sum the query milliseconds over each invocation of the query shape.

While one specific query may be slow at any given time.  The best practice in performance troubleshooting is to optimize the queries that are consuming the maximum total time when aggregated together.  So, a relatively fast query that is extremely common may consume more resources in the mongod than a very rare query that is relatively slower.
toString:
Provide a histogram of commonly slow queries since entering the performance tab or pressing PLAY.  Same as hottest queries but over time.  Sum the query milliseconds over each invocation of the query shape.

While one specific query may be slow at any given time.  The best practice in performance troubleshooting is to optimize the queries that are consuming the maximum total time when aggregated together.  So, a relatively fast query that is extremely common may consume more resources in the mongod than a very rare query that is relatively slower.
author: lucas.hrabovsky

author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: Allow user to rename a collection
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString: Feature request to allow renaming of collections via Compass.
toString: As the comments below indicate there are several feature requests
author: satyendra.sinha

fromString: As the comments below indicate there are several feature requests
toString:
As the comments below indicate there are several feature requests to rename a collection. This can be achieved in the node driver by calling the [rename|http://mongodb.github.io/node-mongodb-native/2.2/api/Collection.html#rename] command on particular collection. The goal of this ticket is to add the UI element, probably an extra option in the sidebar next to ever collection field to edit and call the rename command on the selected collection.

Acceptance Criteria:
* add {{rename}} to data-service (https://github.com/mongodb-js/data-service)
* include unit tests for rename in data-service
* make UI element (On the sidebar) that can be clicked to produce a modal for renaming collection
* add enzyme tests for the above element
* add store action to rename collection that calls the above data-service method
* add unit tests for the above store action
author: satyendra.sinha

fromString: Customers store various types of binary data in MongoDB.  Intercom shows a number of requests to view this data.  This ticket documents conversations requesting the ability to view binary data and attempts to recognize common requests or patterns.
toString:
Customers store various types of binary data in MongoDB.  The Compass chat tool shows a number of requests to view this data.  This ticket documents discussions requesting the ability to view binary data and attempts to recognize common requests or patterns.

Common themes include:
* view GridFS files, including PDFs
* view UUID/GUID components
author: brian.blevins

author: thomasr

fromString:
1. Try to insert the doc with double backslash in one of the values, for example {User: "DOMAIN\\someuser"}
2. Try to query for value containing two backslashes
toString:
Original Content reported by Aleksey: 

1. Try to insert the doc with double backslash in one of the values, for example {User: "DOMAIN\\someuser"}
2. Try to query for value containing two backslashes

Task on this ticket

h4. CRUD 

Document current behavior of "Insert Document" input handling of special character sequences, including

- single backslash
- double backslash
- double-quote
- newline (backslash followed by n)

See e.g. [Single Character Escape Sequences|https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/javascript-escapes] in JavaScript. 

Document what was inserted, how it is stored in MongoDB (e.g. via mongo shell or mongoexport) and how it is displayed in Compass.

h4. Query Bar

Document current behavior of "Query Bar" input handling of special character sequences, including the same as above. What was typed, what query was sent to the server (see e.g. mongo logs with db.setLogLevel(1)).
author: thomasr

Based on the outcome of the reproduction and documentation of current behavior, we can make a decision on what the desired behavior should be and create appropriate tickets to implement this.

For example:
- Add info sprinkle to explain to user
- Create DOCS ticket to turn this report into a user-facing documentation
- Create tickets to resolve inconsistencies between query bar / crud / doc validation / ...



h5. Further Resources and Tools

- http://www.json.org/
- http://bsonspec.org/spec.html
- https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/program/mongoreplay/
- https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/program/bsondump/

fromString:
h2. Original Bug Report 

1. Try to insert the doc with double backslash in one of the values, for example {User: "DOMAIN\\someuser"}
2. Try to query for value containing two backslashes

h2. Task on this ticket

- Document (e.g. in Jira ticket) the behavior for CRUD and Query Bar
- Explain background in a few paragraphs: How does escaping work in Javascript / JSON, how does MongoDB store the string in BSON?

h5. CRUD 

Document current behavior of "Insert Document" input handling of special character sequences, including

- single backslash
- double backslash
- double-quote
- newline (backslash followed by n)

See e.g. [Single Character Escape Sequences|https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/javascript-escapes] in JavaScript. 

Document what was inserted, how it is stored in MongoDB (e.g. inspection via mongo shell or mongoexport) and how it is displayed in Compass.

h5. Query Bar

Document current behavior of "Query Bar" input handling of special character sequences, including the same as above. What was typed, what query was sent to the server (see e.g. mongo logs with db.setLogLevel(1)) and what documents from above were matched with the query.

h5. Future Work 

Based on the outcome of the reproduction and documentation of current behavior, we can make a decision on what the desired behavior should be and create appropriate tickets to implement this.

For example:
- Add info sprinkle to explain to user
- Create DOCS ticket to turn this report into a user-facing documentation
- Create tickets to resolve inconsistencies between query bar / crud / doc validation / ...



h5. Further Resources and Tools

fromString:
Currently, index fetching is done in [mongodb-index-model|https://github.com/mongodb-js/index-model/blob/master/lib/fetch.js]. We want to consolidate all data requests in data-service, and reducing the *-models to simply be data containers, without any dependency on mongodb. 

This ticket represents the task of moving the fetching code to data-service, and populating the index-model there. 

It is orthogonal to, and does not include the refactoring work of "de-ampersanding" the index model (COMPASS-356).
toString:
Currently, index fetching is done in [mongodb-index-model|https://github.com/mongodb-js/index-model/blob/master/lib/fetch.js]. We want to consolidate all data requests in data-service, and reducing the *-models to simply be data containers, without any dependency on mongodb. 

This ticket represents the task of moving the fetching code to data-service, and populating the index-model there. 

It is orthogonal to, and does not include the refactoring work of "de-ampersanding" the index model (COMPASS-356). Data-service would then depend on index-model, pass the raw server response to the model and return a collection of indexes to the caller of {{getIndexes()}}. 

Tasks:

- move the functionality of fetch.js to data-service
- populate the index model (as is, with ampersand) with the data returned from the server
- move fetch.test.js to data-service
- keep index.test.js in index-model
- completely remove dependency on mongodb from index-model
author: thomasr

toString: This issue is depended on by COMPASS-1103
author: lucas.hrabovsky

fromString:
Use 3 points to refactor how Compass initializes into the bootloader used by Slack, N1, Atom and many others:

- Make a new {{./static}} directory
- Move {{./src/app/{images,styles}}} and HTML files into {{./static}}
- Update all image references in the app and hadron-build to point at {{./static}}
- Update hadron-build to write {{./src/compiled-less}} to{{./static}}
- Add {{./static}} to the {{asar.upack}} option in {{hadron-build/commands/release.js}} (they don’t need to be packed)

h3. References 

- [N1 ./static|https://github.com/nylas/N1/tree/master/static]
- [N1’s bootloader.js|https://github.com/nylas/N1/blob/master/static/index.js]
- [Atom ./static|https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/static]
- [Atom’s advanced bootloader.js|https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/static/index.js]

If all goes well, this will negate https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/COMPASS-415
toString:
Use 3 points to refactor how Compass initializes into the bootloader used by Slack, N1, Atom and many others:

- Make a new {{./static}} directory
- Move {{./src/app/{images,styles}}} and HTML files into {{./static}}
- Update all image references in the app and hadron-build to point at {{./static}}
- Update hadron-build to write {{./src/compiled-less}} to{{./static}}
- Add {{./static}} to the {{asar.upack}} option in {{hadron-build/commands/release.js}} (they don’t need to be packed)

Also consider updating any timing code to use [~lucas.hrabovsky] suggestion: https://github.com/nolanlawson/marky

h3. References 

- [N1 ./static|https://github.com/nylas/N1/tree/master/static]
- [N1’s bootloader.js|https://github.com/nylas/N1/blob/master/static/index.js]
- [Atom ./static|https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/static]
- [Atom’s advanced bootloader.js|https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/static/index.js]

toString:
This will improve the Windows installation experience in two ways:
1. Installation assets to be decompressed before installation begins
2. Installation assets trigger less activity like to be disrupted by a virus scanner


- Make a new {{./static}} directory
- Move {{./src/app/{images,styles}}} and HTML files into {{./static}}
- Update all image references in the app and hadron-build to point at {{./static}}
- Update hadron-build to write {{./src/compiled-less}} to{{./static}}
- Add {{./static}} to the {{asar.upack}} option in {{hadron-build/commands/release.js}} (they don’t need to be packed)

Also consider updating any timing code to use [~lucas.hrabovsky] suggestion: https://github.com/nolanlawson/marky

h3. References 

- [N1 ./static|https://github.com/nylas/N1/tree/master/static]
- [N1’s bootloader.js|https://github.com/nylas/N1/blob/master/static/index.js]
- [Atom ./static|https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/static]
- [Atom’s advanced bootloader.js|https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/static/index.js]

If all goes well, this will negate https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/COMPASS-415

fromString:
We have a user in intercom complaining that he gets ssh timeouts, when RoboMongo connects to the instance ok. 

Peter discovered that the current timeout is hardcoded to 5 seconds in Compass. 

Perhaps we should consider increasing the timeout? I wouldn't want to make this configurable if we don't have to, but I don't see a disadvantage of doubling the timeout. If the server rejects the connection, the error will happen immediately, and if it's still trying to connect, the user is probably happy to wait 5 secs longer (rather than not being able to connect at all). 

Intercom conversation: https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/mentions/conversations/7894750563
toString:
We have a user in intercom complaining that he gets ssh timeouts, when RoboMongo connects to the instance ok. 

Peter discovered that the current timeout is [hardcoded to 5 seconds|https://github.com/mongodb-js/connection-model/blob/2002a3df39658665ac9d6713ace525bd35bb2dcb/lib/model.js#L703-L705] in Compass. 

Perhaps we should consider increasing the timeout? I wouldn't want to make this configurable if we don't have to, but I don't see a disadvantage of doubling the timeout. If the server rejects the connection, the error will happen immediately, and if it's still trying to connect, the user is probably happy to wait 5 secs longer (rather than not being able to connect at all). 

Intercom conversation: https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/mentions/conversations/7894750563
author: thomasr

toString:
We have a user in intercom complaining that he gets ssh timeouts, when RoboMongo connects to the instance ok. 

Peter discovered that the current timeout is [hardcoded to 5 seconds|https://github.com/mongodb-js/connection-model/blob/2002a3df39658665ac9d6713ace525bd35bb2dcb/lib/model.js#L703-L705] in the connection-model. 

Perhaps we should consider increasing the timeout? I wouldn't want to make this configurable if we don't have to, but I don't see a disadvantage of doubling the timeout. If the server rejects the connection, the error will happen immediately, and if it's still trying to connect, the user is probably happy to wait 5 secs longer (rather than not being able to connect at all). 

Intercom conversation: https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/mentions/conversations/7894750563

Similar Intercom: https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/p57suhg7/inbox/conversation/8358811725

Possible fix if you have control of the server (perhaps we can document it in https://docs.mongodb.com/compass/current/connect/ ?):
{quote}
For anyone else who wants to speed the login time:
If you edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config on the server and add (if it's not there) at the bottom UseDNS no then restart the SSH daemon with service ssh restart you should see an improvement next time you connect.

We went from 15 seconds to 2 seconds with this change.
{quote}
https://github.com/mscdex/ssh2/issues/142
author: peter.schmidt

toString:
We have a user in intercom complaining that he gets ssh timeouts, when RoboMongo connects to the instance ok. 

Currently, the timeout is [hardcoded to 5 seconds|https://github.com/mongodb-js/connection-model/blob/2002a3df39658665ac9d6713ace525bd35bb2dcb/lib/model.js#L703-L705] in the connection-model. Increase to 30 seconds to account for geo latency.

fromString: Currently, zoom-in is bounded to "Ctrl Shift =" in Linux and Windows. Ideally, this would be changed to just "Ctrl+". Known to affect Redhat; unknown if it affects Ubuntu.
toString:
Currently, zoom-in is bounded to "Ctrl Shift =" in Linux and Windows. Ideally, this would be changed to just "Ctrl+". Known to affect Redhat; unknown if it affects Ubuntu. 

This ticket should implement [electron-localshortcut|https://www.npmjs.com/package/electron-localshortcut] and verify on all platforms.
author: peter.schmidt

fromString:
As a user I would like to personalize Compass:

Some things that I would like it to remember, and open with the same settings next time:

- What size I had the app Window
- What databases were  previously expanded in the side bar
- Whether I prefer tree view or table view when viewing documents 
- Whether I prefer writing JSON or the visual UI when inserting documents
toString:
As a user I would like to personalize Compass:

Some things that I would like it to remember, and open with the same settings next time:

- What size I had the app Window
- What databases were  previously expanded in the side bar
- Whether I prefer tree view or table view when viewing documents 
- Whether I prefer writing JSON or the visual UI when inserting documents 
- What [zoom level|https://mongodb.slack.com/archives/G2L10JAV7/p1502942194000102] I used last time

toString:
When you get to the create index via Compass and don't specify an index name, it gets auto-generated after you hit the create index button. While this is expected, the UI encourages the user to fill in an index name.
My suggestion is to do one of the following:
1. Move the Index Name to an "advanced" section and put a note that it will be auto-generated in case it's not filled
2. Show the auto-generated index name after the user picks field names/types
author: jessica.sigafoos
